Cherry Ave, Tucson, AZ 85721, USA), BF(Max-Planck-Institut f ur Extraterrestrische Physik (MPE), Giessenbachstr., D-85748, Garching, Germany), BG(European Space Agency (ESA), ESA Office, Space Telescope Science Institute, 3700 San Martin Drive, Baltimore, MD 21218, USA), BH(SKA Organisation, Lower Withington, Macclesfield, Cheshire SK11 9DL, UK)"], "journal_name": "The Astrophysical Journal", "volume": "911", "publication_year": "2021/04/1", "start_page": "99", "keywords": ["Galaxy evolution", "Galaxy formation", "High-redshift galaxies", "Interstellar medium", "Strong gravitational lensing", "Galaxy kinematics", "Luminosity function", "594", "595", "734", "847", "1643", "602", "942", "Astrophysics - Astrophysics of Galaxies", "Astrophysics - Cosmology and Nongalactic Astrophysics"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2021ApJ...911...99F", "abstract": "We present bright [C II] 158 \u03bcm line detections from a strongly magnified and multiply imaged (\u03bc \u223c 20-160) sub-L<SUP>*</SUP> ( ${M}_{\\mathrm{UV}}=-{19.75}_{-0.44}^{+0.55}$ ) Lyman-break galaxy (LBG) at z = 6.0719 \u00b1 0.0004, drawn from the ALMA Lensing Cluster Survey (ALCS). Emission lines are identified at 268.7 GHz at \u22658\u03c3 exactly at the positions of two multiple images of the LBG, behind the massive galaxy cluster RXCJ0600-2007. Our lens models, updated with the latest spectroscopy from VLT/MUSE, indicate that a sub region of the LBG crosses the caustic, and is lensed into a long (\u223c6\u2033) arc with a local magnification of \u03bc \u223c 160, for which the [C II] line is also significantly detected. The source plane reconstruction resolves the interstellar medium (ISM) structure, showing that the [C II] line is co-spatial with the rest-frame UV continuum at a scale of \u223c300 pc. The [C II] line properties suggest that the LBG is a rotation-dominated system, whose velocity gradient explains a slight difference in redshifts between the whole LBG and its sub-region. The star formation rate (SFR)-L<SUB>[CII]</SUB> relations, for whole and sub-regions of the LBG, are consistent with those of local galaxies. We evaluate the lower limit of the faint-end of the [C II] luminosity function at z = 6, finding it to be consistent with predictions from semi-analytical models and from the local SFR-L<SUB>[CII]</SUB> relation with a SFR function at z = 6. These results imply that the local SFR-L<SUB>[CII]</SUB> relation is universal for a wide range of scales, including the spatially resolved ISM, the whole region of the galaxy, and the cosmic scale, even in the epoch of reionization.", "doi": "10.3847/1538-4357/abd7ec", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:2101.01937", "issn": "0004-637X", "number": "2"}, "ADS link": itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Periodical\">\n        <a name=\"\" id=\"skip-to-content-link-target\" tabindex=\"-1\"></a>\n        <div class=\"wrapper grid-3-col da-showgrid ta-showgrid cf\">\n    <main role=\"main\">\n        <!-- Secondary header starts -->\n<div class=\"secondary-header cf\" id=\"wd-secondary-header\">\n    <!-- Branded journal header starts -->\n<div class=\"big-branded\">\n\n    <div class=\"publication-name\" id=\"wd-pub-name\">\n\t<div class=\"publication-title\" itemprop=\"name\" itemid=\"periodical\">\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Journal image link tile starts -->\n<!-- Logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"/journal/0004-637X\" itemprop=\"url\">\n    <img src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8febf88b-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/apj-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Astrophysical Journal\">\n</a>\n<!-- Logo tile ends -->\n<!-- Journal image link tile ends -->\n</div>\n\t\t</div>\n    <div class=\"partner-logos m-hide\" id=\"wd-partner-logos\">\n            <div class=\"partner-logo-alignment\">\n                <!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The American Astronomical Society (AAS), established in 1899 and based in Washington, DC, is the major organization of professional astronomers in North America. Its membership of about 7,000 individuals also includes physicists, mathematicians, geologists, engineers, and others whose research and educational interests lie within the broad spectrum of subjects comprising contemporary astronomy. The mission of the AAS is to enhance and share humanity's scientific understanding of the universe.</p> <p><a href=\"https://aas.org/\">https://aas.org/</a></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The Institute of Physics (IOP) is a leading scientific society promoting physics and bringing physicists together for the benefit of all. It has a worldwide membership of around 50 000 comprising physicists from all sectors, as well as those with an interest in physics. It works to advance physics research, application and education; and engages with policy makers and the public to develop awareness and understanding of physics. Its publishing company, IOP Publishing, is a world leader in professional scientific communications.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.iop.org\">https://www.iop.org</a></p></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<p></p>\n                </div>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n<!-- Branded journal header ends -->\n</div> <span class=\"icon-newtab\">\n            </a></p>\n        </div>\n\n    <!-- End Email Alert -->\n<!-- End Email Alert --><!-- Start Citation Alert Link -->\n                        <p>\n<div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper\">\n    <a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert\" href=\"https://myiopscience.iop.org/signin?origin=a0&return=https%3A%2F%2Fiopscience.iop.org%2Fmyiopscience%2Falerts%2Fsubscribe%3FarticleID%3D0004-637X%2F911%2F2%2F99\"><span\n            class=\"icon-alarm icon-alarm--jhp\"></span>Create citation alert</a>\n</div><!-- End Citation Alert Link -->\n                    </div>\n\t\t</div>\n    </div>\n    <!-- Article information ends -->\n<!-- Start Info top-->\n    <!-- end Info top --><div class=\"article-content\">\n\t<span id=\"articleId\" class=\"hide\">0004-637X/911/2/99</span>\n<!-- Start Abstract -->\n    <h2 id=\"artAbst\" class=\"collapse-blocked\">Abstract</h2>\n        <!-- Start article video abstract -->\n\t<!-- End article video abstract -->\n\t<div class=\"article-text wd-jnl-art-abstract cf\" itemprop=\"description\">\n            <p>We present bright [C <span style=\"font-variant: small-caps\">ii</span>] 158 <i>\u03bc</i>m line detections from a strongly magnified and multiply imaged (<i>\u03bc</i> \u223c 20\u2013160) sub\u2013<i>L</i><sup>*</sup> (<img alt=\"${M}_{\\mathrm{UV}}=-{19.75}_{-0.44}^{+0.55}$\" src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn1.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=14kXSQqv720jw2DsKiHowD37Slw%3D\"></img>) Lyman-break galaxy (LBG) at <i>z</i> = 6.0719 \u00b1 0.0004, drawn from the ALMA Lensing Cluster Survey (ALCS). Emission lines are identified at 268.7 GHz at \u22658<i>\u03c3</i> exactly at the positions of two multiple images of the LBG, behind the massive galaxy cluster RXCJ0600\u22122007. Our lens models, updated with the latest spectroscopy from VLT/MUSE, indicate that a sub region of the LBG crosses the caustic, and is lensed into a long (\u223c6'') arc with a local magnification of <i>\u03bc</i> \u223c 160, for which the [C <span style=\"font-variant: small-caps\">ii</span>] line is also significantly detected. The source plane reconstruction resolves the interstellar medium (ISM) structure, showing that the [C <span style=\"font-variant: small-caps\">ii</span>] line is co-spatial with the rest-frame UV continuum at a scale of \u223c300 pc. The [C <span style=\"font-variant: small-caps\">ii</span>] line properties suggest that the LBG is a rotation-dominated system, whose velocity gradient explains a slight difference in redshifts between the whole LBG and its sub-region. The star formation rate (SFR)\u2013<i>L</i><sub>[CII]</sub> relations, for whole and sub-regions of the LBG, are consistent with those of local galaxies. We evaluate the lower limit of the faint-end of the [C <span style=\"font-variant: small-caps\">ii</span>] luminosity function at <i>z</i> = 6, finding it to be consistent with predictions from semi-analytical models and from the local SFR\u2013<i>L</i><sub>[CII]</sub> relation with a SFR function at <i>z</i> = 6. These results imply that the local SFR\u2013<i>L</i><sub>[CII]</sub> relation is universal for a wide range of scales, including the spatially resolved ISM, the whole region of the galaxy, and the cosmic scale, even in the epoch of reionization.</p></div>\n    <!-- End abstract -->\n<!-- Start Export citation and abstract tools -->\n\t<p>\n\t\t<small>Export citation and abstract</small>\n\t\t<span class=\"btn-multi-block\">\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/911/2/99&doi=10.3847/1538-4357/abd7ec&exportFormat=iopexport_bib&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-bib\" title=\"Export BibTex\">BibTeX</a>\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/911/2/99&doi=10.3847/1538-4357/abd7ec&exportFormat=iopexport_ris&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-ris\" title=\"Export RIS\">RIS</a>\n\t\t</span>\n\t</p>\n<!-- End Export citation and abstract tools -->\n<div class=\"linked-articles linked-articles--issue-nav\">\n\t<div class=\"linked-articles__wrapper\">\n\t\t<div class=\"linked-articles__prev\">\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/article/10.3847/1538-4357/abe1b9\"\n\t\t\t   class=\"linked-articles__btn event_read-more-articles\" data-event-action=\"Previous Article\"><span class=\"fa-icon\"><svg\n\t\t\t\t\taria-hidden=\"true\" focusable=\"false\" xmlns=\"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg\" viewBox=\"0 0 192 14.142z\"></path></svg></span><b>Previous</b> article in issue</a>\n\t\t</div>\n\t\t<div class=\"linked-articles__next\">\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/article/10.3847/1538-4357/abedba\"\n\t\t\t   class=\"linked-articles__btn event_read-more-articles\" data-event-action=\"Next Article\"><b>Next</b> article in issue<span\n\t\t\t\t\tclass=\"fa-icon fa-icon--right\"><svg aria-hidden=\"true\" focusable=\"false\"\n\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\t\txmlns=\"http://www.w3.org/2000/svg\" viewBox=\"0 0 192 512\"><path\n\t\t\t\t\td=\"M0 384.662V127.338c0-17.818 21.543-26.741 34.142-14.142l128.662 128.662c7.81 7.81 7.81 20.474 0 28.284L34.142 398.804C21.543 411.404 0 402.48 0 384.662z\"></path></svg></span></a>\n\t\t</div>\n\t\t</div>\n</div>\n<!-- Start AAS Related Links -->\n<div class=\"reveal-container reveal-closed reveal-plus-icon bdt-1 mt-2 mb-2 wd-jnl-art-article-aas-related-links\">\n  <div class=\"replica-h3 mt-0\">\n    <a href=\"#\" class=\"reveal-trigger\" data-reveal-label-alt=\"Hide related links\">Related links</a>\n  </div>\n  <div class=\"reveal-content\">\n    <div class=\"article-meta\"> \n      <ul>\n      \t<li><a href=\"https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2021ApJ...911...99F\" target=\"_blank\">NASA ADS Record <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-ref?querymethod=bib&simbo=on&bibcode=2021ApJ...911...99F\" target=\"_blank\">Simbad Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"/journal/0004-637X/page/About%20Related%20Links\" target=\"_blank\">About Related Links</a></li>\n      \t</ul>\n    </div>\n  </div>\n</div>\n<!-- Start info bottom -->\n    <!-- End info bottom -->\n<!-- Start article full text -->\n\t<div xmlns:book=\"http://api.iop.org/Book/1.0/\" itemprop=\"articleBody\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-full-text article-text\"><h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjabd7ecs1\" name=\"apjabd7ecs1\">1.\u00a0Introduction</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Galaxy evolution is regulated by several key mechanisms in the interstellar medium (ISM), such as disk formation, stellar and active galactic nuclei (AGN) feedback, mass building via star formation and galaxy mergers, and clump formations due to disk instabilities. Resolving the ISM structure to study local physical properties in high-redshift galaxies is thus essential in order to understand the initial phase of galaxy formation and evolution.</p><p>During recent decades, hundreds of star-forming galaxies at <em>z</em> &gt; 6 have been spectroscopically identified, primarily with Ly<em>\u03b1</em> lines (e.g., Iye et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib64\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib64\">2006</a>; Vanzella et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib137\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib137\">2011</a>; Pentericci et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib104\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib104\">2011</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib106\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib106\">2014</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib105\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib105\">2018</a>; Shibuya et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib117\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib117\">2012</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib119\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib119\">2018</a>; Ono et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib100\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib100\">2012</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib99\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib99\">2018</a>; Finkelstein et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib38\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib38\">2013</a>; Oesch et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib96\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib96\">2015</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib95\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib95\">2016</a>; Stark et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib125\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib125\">2017</a>; Higuchi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib60\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib60\">2019</a>). The Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) offers a rest-frame far-infrared (FIR) spectroscopic window for these <em>z</em> &gt; 6 galaxies, especially with bright fine-structure lines of [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] 158 <em>\u03bc</em>m and [O <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] 88 <em>\u03bc</em>m (e.g., Maiolino et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib80\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib80\">2015</a>; Inoue et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib63\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib63\">2016</a>; Pentericci et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib103\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib103\">2016</a>; Knudsen et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib70\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib70\">2016</a>; Matthee et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib86\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib86\">2017</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib85\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib85\">2019</a>; Carniani et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib18\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib18\">2018</a>; Smit et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib120\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib120\">2018</a>; Bowler et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib9\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib9\">2018</a>; Hashimoto et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib55\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib55\">2018</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib54\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib54\">2019</a>; Tamura et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib131\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib131\">2019</a>; Fujimoto et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib42\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib42\">2019</a>; Bakx et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib3\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib3\">2020</a>). Since heavy elements produced in stars are returned into the ISM, the metal gas properties traced by these fine-structure lines represent good probes of star formation history and related physical mechanisms (Maiolino &amp; Mannucci <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib81\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib81\">2019</a>). In fact, recent ALMA spatial and kinematic [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]-line studies have identified signatures of some key mechanisms, including disk rotations (e.g., Jones et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib66\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib66\">2017</a>; Smit et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib120\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib120\">2018</a>), galaxy mergers (e.g., Hashimoto et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib54\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib54\">2019</a>; Le F\u00e8vre et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib76\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib76\">2020</a>), and outflows (e.g., Gallerani et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib46\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib46\">2018</a>; Spilker et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib123\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib123\">2018</a>; Fujimoto et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib42\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib42\">2019</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib44\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib44\">2020b</a>; Ginolfi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib48\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib48\">2020</a>). In conjunction with other fine-structure lines of [O <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] and [N <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], recent ALMA observations also allow us to perform multiple line diagnostics to constrain the dominant ionization state of the ISM gas (e.g., Inoue et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib63\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib63\">2016</a>; Pavesi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib101\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib101\">2016</a>; Laporte et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib75\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib75\">2019</a>; Novak et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib93\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib93\">2019</a>; Harikane et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib52\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib52\">2020</a>).</p><p>There are several challenges associated with FIR spectroscopy. The first is sensitivity. While ALMA is the most sensitive mm/submm telescope, yielding a large number of new findings about high-redshift galaxies, the detection of FIR fine-structure lines from abundant, typical galaxies remains challenging. For example, to observe a [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line of \u223c 1 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>8</sup> \n            <em>L</em><sub>\u2299</sub> from <em>z</em> = 6, an observation time of about 2 h is required.<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecfn1\">\n               32\n            </a></sup>\n             However, such a source typically falls in the absolute UV magnitude range of <em>M</em><sub>UV</sub> \u223c \u221222.0 \u2013 \u221221.5 mag (see e.g., Table 7 in Hashimoto et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib54\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib54\">2019</a>). This absolute UV magnitude range is \u223c2\u20133 times brighter than the characteristic luminosity, <em>L</em><sup>*</sup>, in the UV luminosity function at <em>z</em> &gt; 6 (e.g., Ono et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib99\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib99\">2018</a>), indicating that \u227310 h observation time is necessary to study the abundant, typical galaxies with <em>L</em><sup>*</sup> or sub-<em>L</em><sup>*</sup> luminosities. The second challenge is high spatial resolution observations toward these typical galaxies. Recent Hubble Space Telescope (HST) studies report that the typical effective radius (<em>r</em><sub>e</sub>) in star-forming galaxies at <em>z</em> &gt; 6 is estimated to be &lt;1 kpc (\u22430<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />2) (e.g., Holwerda et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib62\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib62\">2015</a>; Shibuya et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib118\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib118\">2015</a>; Bouwens et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib8\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib8\">2017</a>; Kawamata et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib68\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib68\">2018</a>). The ISM structure most comparable to the <em>r</em><sub>e</sub> scale could be resolved by ALMA high-resolution observations down to the 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />02 scale. However, this requires even longer observation times than the \u227310 h estimated above, just for the detection of the typical galaxies. The third challenge is the requirement for prior spectroscopic redshifts due to the narrow frequency coverage of ALMA (7.5 GHz coverage in a single tuning), which may cause potential biases. In most cases, the prior spectroscopic redshift is obtained from Ly<em>\u03b1</em> lines. While high-redshift galaxies with Ly<em>\u03b1</em> spectroscopic redshifts show weak [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] lines at a given star formation rate (Carniani et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib18\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib18\">2018</a>; Harikane et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib53\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib53\">2018</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib52\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib52\">2020</a>; but see Schaerer et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib116\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib116\">2020</a>), a recent study by Smit et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib120\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib120\">2018</a>) indicates that galaxies with no strong Ly<em>\u03b1</em> line may emit a strong [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line. Since the fraction of Ly<em>\u03b1</em> emitters (LAEs; e.g., equivalent width of Ly<em>\u03b1</em> &gt; 25 \u00c5) is less than 30% among star-forming galaxies with <em>M</em><sub>UV</sub> \u223c \u221221.5 mag at <em>z</em> &gt; 6 (e.g., Stark et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib126\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib126\">2011</a>; Treu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib134\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib134\">2013</a>; Tilvi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib133\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib133\">2014</a>; De Barros et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib26\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib26\">2017</a>; Pentericci et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib105\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib105\">2018</a>; Kusakabe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib73\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib73\">2020</a>), follow-up observations of only those galaxies with secure Ly<em>\u03b1</em> lines will systematically miss a majority of the representative population at <em>z</em> &gt; 6. An ALMA blind line survey is one possible solution, but novel [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line emitters <em>z</em> &gt; 6 have not yet been identified, due to the lack of sufficiently deep and large survey volumes (e.g., Matsuda et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib84\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib84\">2015</a>; Aravena et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib1\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib1\">2016</a>; Yamaguchi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib140\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib140\">2017</a>; Hayatsu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib57\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib57\">2019</a>; Decarli et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib28\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib28\">2020</a>; Romano et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib113\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib113\">2020</a>; Yan et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib141\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib141\">2020</a>).</p><p>In this paper, we report the blind detection of bright [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] 158 <em>\u03bc</em>m lines from strongly lensed multiple images of a sub-<em>L</em><sup>*</sup> galaxy at <em>z</em> = 6.0719 behind the massive galaxy cluster RXCJ0600\u22122007, drawn from the ALMA Lensing Cluster Survey (ALCS). Making full use of large ancillary data sets, including HST, Spitzer, and VLT, and with help of gravitational lensing magnification, we resolve the ISM structures and investigate the spatially resolved rest-frame UV-to-FIR continuum, and the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line properties down to a \u2243300 pc scale. This is the first ALMA study to resolve the ISM properties in a representative (\u2243sub-<em>L</em><sup>*</sup>) galaxy in the epoch of reionization.</p><p>The structure of this paper is as follows: in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs2\">2</a>, we overview the ALCS survey and the data sets in RXCJ0600\u22122007, as well as strong lensing mass models of the cluster. Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3\">3</a> outlines methods of blind line identification, and the optical\u2013near-infrared (NIR) properties of the two [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line emitters at <em>z</em> = 6.07. In Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs4\">4</a>, we report and discuss the intrinsic characteristics of these two [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line emitters together with the correction of the lensing magnification. A summary of this study is presented in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs5\">5</a>. Throughout this paper, we assume the Chabrier initial mass function (Chabrier <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib19\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib19\">2003</a>) and a flat universe, where \u03a9<sub>m</sub> = 0.3, \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub> = 0.7, <em>\u03c3</em><sub>8</sub> = 0.8, and <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 70 km s<sup>\u22121</sup> Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>. We use magnitudes in the AB system (Oke &amp; Gunn <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib98\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib98\">1983</a>).</p></div><h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjabd7ecs2\" name=\"apjabd7ecs2\">2.\u00a0Data and Reduction</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><h3 id=\"apjabd7ecs2-1\" name=\"apjabd7ecs2-1\">2.1.\u00a0ALMA Lensing Cluster Survey</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>ALCS is a cycle-6 ALMA large program (Project ID: 2018.1.00035.L; PI: K. Kohno) to map a total of 88 arcmin<sup>2</sup> high-magnification regions in 33 massive galaxy clusters at 1.2 mm in Band 6. The sample is selected from the best-studied clusters drawn from HST treasury programs, i.e., the Cluster Lensing And Supernova Survey with Hubble (CLASH; Postman et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib110\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib110\">2012</a>), Hubble Frontier Fields (HFF; Lotz et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib78\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib78\">2017</a>), and the Reionization Lensing Cluster Survey (RELICS; Coe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib22\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib22\">2019</a>). Observations were carried out between 2018 December and 2019 December, in compact array configurations of C43-1 and C43-2, fine-tuned to recover strongly lensed (i.e., spatially elongated), low surface brightness sources. The 1.2 mm mapping is accomplished by means of a 15 GHz wide spectral scan in the ranges of 250.0\u2013257.5 GHz and 265.0\u2013272.5 GHz via two frequency setups, so as to enlarge the survey volume for line-emitting galaxies. The spectral mode of Time Division Mode is used, which achieves a spectral resolution of \u223c28 km s<sup>\u22121</sup> with these frequency setups. A full description of the survey and its main objectives will be presented in a separate paper (currently in preparation).</p></div><h3 id=\"apjabd7ecs2-2\" name=\"apjabd7ecs2-2\">2.2.\u00a0RXCJ0600\u22122007</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>RXCJ0600\u22122007 is a massive (\u223c10<sup>15</sup> \n               <em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub>) galaxy cluster at <em>z</em> = 0.43, which is included in RELICS, and was first identified in the Massive Cluster Survey (MACS; Ebeling et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib35\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib35\">2001</a>). As a part of ALCS, the ALMA observations for RXCJ0600\u22122007 were performed in 2019 January, mapping the central area of 230'' <b>&#x00d7;</b> 90'' in 105 pointings with 46\u201349 12 m antennae, and providing baselines of 15\u2013456 m under a precipitable water vapor (PWV) of 0.6\u20131.3 mm. J0522-3627 was observed as a flux calibrator. The bandpass and phase calibrations were performed with J0609-1542.</p><p>The ALMA data were reduced and calibrated using the Common Astronomy Software Applications package version 5.4.0 (<span class=\"small-caps\">casa</span>; McMullin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib88\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib88\">2007</a>) with the pipeline script, in the standard manner. With the CASA task <span class=\"small-caps\">tclean</span>, continuum maps were produced by utilizing all spectral windows. The <span class=\"small-caps\">tclean</span> routines were executed down to the 3<em>\u03c3</em> level. We adopted a pixel scale of 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />15, and a common spectral channel bin of 30 km s<sup>\u22121</sup>. The natural-weighted map achieved a synthesized beam FWHM of 1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />22 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />95, with sensitivities in the continuum and the line in a 30 km s<sup>\u22121</sup> width channel of 56.9 and 932 <em>\u03bc</em>Jy beam<sup>\u22121</sup>, respectively. We also produced several <em>uv</em>-tapered maps in a parameter range of 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />8 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />8 to 1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />8 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />8 to obtain spatially integrated properties where necessary. Throughout the paper, we used the natural-weighted map unless otherwise specified.</p><p>HST/ACS\u2013WFC3 and Spitzer/IRAC observations were carried out as a part of the RELICS (Coe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib22\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib22\">2019</a>) and Spitzer\u2013RELICS (Strait et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib127\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib127\">2020</a>) surveys, respectively. HST images were obtained in the F606W (2180 s), F814W (3565 s), F105W (1411 s), F125W (711 s), F140W (736 s), and F160W (1961 s) filters. The IRAC channel 1 (3.6 <em>\u03bc</em>m) and channel 2 (4.5<em>\u03bc</em>m) integrations are approximately 10 hours each. We aligned all of the HST exposures to sources in the PanSTARRS (DR1) catalog (Chambers et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib20\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib20\">2016</a>; Flewelling et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib39\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib39\">2020</a>)\u2014which we verified as consistent with the GAIA DR2 (Gaia Collaboration et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib45\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib45\">2018</a>) astrometric frame\u2014and created final mosaics in a common pixel frame with 50 mas and 100 mas pixels for the ACS/WFC and WFC3/IR filters, respectively. We aligned the individual Spitzer exposures to the same astrometric frame, and generated final drizzled IRAC mosaics with a pixel scale of 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5. Further details of the HST (Spitzer) image processing, using <tt>grizli</tt> (<tt>golfir</tt>) software, will be presented in V. Kokorev et al. (2021, in preparation). In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjabd7ecf1\">1</a>, we present a false-color HST image of RXCJ0600\u22122007.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjabd7ecf1\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjabd7ecf1\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf1_lr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=JXHAnOpp4AqIHxCDGbOWrErU0qM%3D\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 1.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 1.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf1_lr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=JXHAnOpp4AqIHxCDGbOWrErU0qM%3D\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 1.</strong>\u00a0Left: false-color HST image of the cluster RXCJ0600\u22122007 (red: F160W, green: F125W, blue: F814W). The white line denotes the critical curve at <em>z</em> = 6.07, estimated from our fiducial mass model. The green lines indicate the ALCS area coverage in this cluster, within which the relative sensitivity to the deepest part of the mosaic map is greater than 30%. The five multiple image positions of RXCJ0600-<em>z</em>6 are marked with yellow 6'' <b>&#x00d7;</b> 6'' squares. Middle: HST/F160W 6'' <b>&#x00d7;</b> 6'' cutouts for multiple images of <em>z</em>6.1/6.2, <em>z</em>6.3, and <em>z</em>6.4 (from top to bottom). The red contours denote the velocity-integrated [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line intensity, drawn at 1<em>\u03c3</em> intervals from \u00b12<em>\u03c3</em> to \u00b18<em>\u03c3</em>. We use the natural-weighted map for <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3, while using the <em>uv</em>-tapered (1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />8 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />8) map for <em>z</em>6.4 to obtain the optimized S/N. The ALMA synthesized beams are presented in the bottom left. The black bars indicate foreground sources. The foreground source overlapping <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 is subtracted in our optical\u2013NIR analysis with <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> (see Section <a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-2\">3.2</a> and Appendix <a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecapp3\">C</a>; see also Laporte et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib144\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib144\">2021</a>). Right: [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line spectra for <em>z</em>6.1/6.2, <em>z</em>6.3, and <em>z</em>6.4 from top to bottom, obtained from the ALCS data cube. The yellow shade indicates the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] integration range for the velocity-integrated map, whose contours are shown in the middle panel. The blue curve is the best-fit single Gaussian.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjabd7ecf1\" href=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf1_lr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=JXHAnOpp4AqIHxCDGbOWrErU0qM%3D\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjabd7ecf1\" href=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf1_hr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=5t%2FtTDxrBscVuckVVGdvdnQwg00%3D\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>VLT/MUSE integral field spectroscopy of the RXCJ0600\u22122007 field was obtained on 2018 January 26th (ESO program ID 0100.A-0792, P.I.: A. Edge). The 0.8 h observation was split into three exposures of 970 s each, centered on the brightest cluster galaxy (BCG), and covering 1 arcmin<sup>2</sup> of the cluster core. We use the standard MUSE reduction pipeline version 2.8.1 (Weilbacher et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib138\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib138\">2014</a>) to create the final data cube. In this process, we used the self-calibration method, based on the MUSE Python Data Analysis Framework (Bacon et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib2\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib2\">2016</a>; Piqueras et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib107\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib107\">2017</a>), and implemented in this version of the reduction pipeline. Finally, we applied the Zurich Atmosphere Purge (ZAP, Soto et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib122\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib122\">2016</a>) to remove those sky residuals not completely removed by the MUSE pipeline.</p><p>We used the MUSE data cube to build our redshift catalog in two steps, similarly to Caminha et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib14\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib14\">2017</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib15\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib15\">2019</a>). We first extracted the spectra of all sources detected in the HST imaging, and in a second step, we performed a blind search for faint-line emitters. This procedure allowed us to measure 76 secure redshifts, of which 16 are emissions from galaxies behind the cluster. This redshift catalog was used to identify the cluster members and multiply imaged galaxies used in strong lens mass modeling (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-3\">3.3</a> for more details). In Appendix <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecapp1\">A</a>, we summarize the full spectroscopic sample from MUSE.</p></div></div><h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjabd7ecs3\" name=\"apjabd7ecs3\">3.\u00a0Data Analysis</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><h3 id=\"apjabd7ecs3-1\" name=\"apjabd7ecs3-1\">3.1.\u00a0Line Identification</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>We conduct a blind line search in the ALMA data cubes, with channel widths of 30 and 60 km s<sup>\u22121</sup>. Firstly, we produce three-dimensional signal-to-noise ratio (S/N) cubes by dividing each channel with its standard deviation. Here we use the ALMA data cubes prior to primary beam correction. We then search line candidates in the three-dimensional S/N cube, utilizing the python-based software, <span class=\"small-caps\">dendrogram</span> (Goodman et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib50\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib50\">2009</a>), whose algorithm is similar to <span class=\"small-caps\">clumpfind</span> (Williams et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib139\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib139\">1994</a>). In <span class=\"small-caps\">dendrogram</span>, we obtain an initial candidate catalog of line sources meeting the following criteria: at least 10 pixels and/or channels with a pixel value of \u22652 (i.e., S/N \u2265 2). Performing the same procedure in the negative peaks in the S/N cubes, under the assumption that the noise is Gaussian, <span class=\"small-caps\">dendrogram</span> evaluates the reliability of the initial line candidates based on the positive and negative properties of the peak S/N histograms, spatially-integrated pixel values, and channel width. This results in two reliable, bright-line emitters, both at \u223c268.7 GHz. We note that these two lines are also robustly identified via the independent blind line search method of Gonz\u00e1lez-L\u00f3pez et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib49\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib49\">2017</a>). Based on the morphological, redshift, and gravitational lens properties of the two line emitters obtained, in the detailed analyses in the following subsections (Sections <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-2\">3.2</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-3\">3.3</a>, and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-4\">3.4</a>), we refer to these two line emitters as <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 (=<em>z</em>6.1 and <em>z</em>6.2) and <em>z</em>6.3 throughout this paper.</p><p>In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjabd7ecf1\">1</a>, we present the ALMA spectra and the velocity-integrated intensity (i.e., moment 0) maps of <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3. Note that <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 shows an elongated morphology with two peaks in the moment 0 map. Although there is a possibility that a combination of the diffuse continuum and noise fluctuation causes multiple peaks (e.g., Hodge et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib61\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib61\">2016</a>), we confirm in Appendix <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecapp2\">B</a> that the two peaks in <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 are not caused by this combination, via a realistic simulation. A single Gaussian fit to <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3 in the line spectra is summarized in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjabd7ect1\">1</a>. Although we obtain consistent full-width-at-half-maximum (FWHM) values for the line widths between <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3, their frequency peaks differ slightly, by 69 \u00b1 22 km s<sup>\u22121</sup>. Subsequent to integration over a velocity range of 1.5 <b>&#x00d7;</b> FWHM, <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3 have S/N values of 9.2 and 8.0 at the peak pixels, respectively. A single elliptical Gaussian fit over a spatial area of 6'' <b>&#x00d7;</b> 6'' in the velocity-integrated maps, using the CASA <span class=\"small-caps\">imfit</span> task, yields deconvolved spatial FWHM sizes of 4<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />24 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />82, and 1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />17 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />29 for <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3, respectively. To obtain the integrated property, here we use a <em>uv</em>-tapered (1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />0 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />0) map for <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 in <span class=\"small-caps\">imfit</span>. From line free channels, the continuum is also detected in the <em>uv</em>-tapered map (2<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />0 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 2<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />0) at 4.5<em>\u03c3</em> and 2.5<em>\u03c3</em> level from <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3, respectively. We also summarize the <span class=\"small-caps\">imfit</span> results and the continuum flux density in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjabd7ect1\">1</a>. Further analyses of the continuum emission are presented in Laporte et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib144\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib144\">2021</a>).</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjabd7ect1\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 1.</b>\u00a0Observed FIR Properties of Bright [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] Line Emitters Identified in RXCJ0600\u22122007</p><table <strong>Notes. S/N</strong>: Signal-to-noise ratio at the peak pixel in the natural-weighted map, after velocity integration. The velocity integration range is denoted by the yellow shaded region in the right panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjabd7ecf1\">1</a>. <em>\u03bd</em><sub>center</sub> \n                     <strong>&amp; FWHM</strong>: [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line peak frequency and full-width-at-half-maximum estimated from a single Gaussian fit. <em>z</em><sub>[CII]</sub>: Redshift of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line emission estimated from the frequency peak. <em>S</em><sub>[CII]</sub> &amp; <em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub>: The velocity-integrated [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line intensity and the line luminosity with optimized apertures. Here we adopt a velocity integration range of 1.5 <b>&#x00d7;</b> FWHM. <em>f</em><sub>1.2mm</sub>: Peak 1.2 mm continuum flux density in a <em>uv</em>-tapered (2<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />0 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 2<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />0) map. We provide a 2<em>\u03c3</em> upper limit for <em>z</em>6.4. [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] major-/minor-axis &amp; position angle: De-convolved spatial size (in FWHM) and position angle of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line in the velocity-integrated map measured with <span class=\"small-caps\">imfit</span>. For <em>z</em>6.1/6.2, we use a <em>uv</em>-tapered (1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />0 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />0) map to obtain the global scale property.</p><a name=\"apjabd7ect1fna\" id=\"apjabd7ect1fna\"></a><sup> \n                        a\n                     </sup>This source is also referred to as RXCJ0060-arc in Laporte et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib144\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib144\">2021</a>).<a name=\"apjabd7ect1fnb\" id=\"apjabd7ect1fnb\"></a><sup> \n                        b\n                     </sup>We do not perform any profile fitting to the spectrum and the 2D spatial map of <em>z</em>6.4, due to its faintness. We adopt the FWHM and the peak frequency associated with <em>z</em>6.3 to calculate the velocity-integrated intensity of the line.<a name=\"apjabd7ect1fnc\" id=\"apjabd7ect1fnc\"></a><sup> \n                        c\n                     </sup>\n                        <em>z</em>6.5 falls outside of the ALCS area coverage.</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/911/2/99/suppdata/apjabd7ect1_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/abd7ec\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ect1_lr.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=NvhYr0GXfNosTHEXvc2EVIupp5E%3D\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div></div><h3 id=\"apjabd7ecs3-2\" name=\"apjabd7ecs3-2\">3.2.\u00a0Optical\u2013NIR Counterparts</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The bright lines of <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3 at \u223c268.7 GHz could be CO or [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] (e.g., Decarli et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib28\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib28\">2020</a>). To determine which line corresponds to <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3, we investigate their optical to near-infrared (NIR) properties. In the top panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjabd7ecf2\">2</a>, we show optical\u2013NIR HST images around <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3. From the line peak positions, we identify clear counterparts in the optical\u2013NIR images within a spatial offset of \u223c 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />1 for both <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3. Both counterparts have a noticeable dropout feature blueward of \u223c1 <em>\u03bc</em>m, with the one near <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 exhibiting a highly elongated shape, aligned with the elongated shape in the 268.684 GHz line. In the highly elongated object near <em>z</em>6.1/6.2, we identify a compact source at the center, whose optical\u2013NIR color is distinct from the other parts of the elongated object, and is indicative of a chance overlapping foreground object. We carefully model and subtract this foreground object (see Appendix <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecapp3\">C</a>) to study the elongated object near <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 in the subsequent analysis. Northeast of <em>z</em>6.3, we also identify a nearby compact object. This has a photometric redshift of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn2.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=laHCKhitnVX8sePW9PNqH4nAhuU%3D\" alt=\"${0.50}_{-0.32}^{+0.05}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{0.50}_{-0.32}^{+0.05}</script></span></span> (V. Kokorev et al. 2021, in preparation), and is presumably one of the member galaxies of RXCJ0600-2007 (<em>z</em> = 0.43), but does not affect the photometry of <em>z</em>6.3.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjabd7ecf2\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjabd7ecf2\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf2_lr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=px9avYzMHlVSdtVxZlQhduuKNQw%3D\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 2.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 2.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf2_lr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=px9avYzMHlVSdtVxZlQhduuKNQw%3D\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 2.</strong>\u00a0Observed optical\u2013NIR properties of <em>z</em>6.1/6.2, <em>z</em>6.3, <em>z</em>6.4, and <em>z</em>6.5, consistently predicted as multiple images of a background LBG at <em>z</em> \u223c 6 from different mass models (except for <em>z</em>6.5, whose identification as a multiple image is tentative). Top: cutouts of the HST (3'' <b>&#x00d7;</b> 3'', except for <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 with 6'' <b>&#x00d7;</b> 6'') and Spitzer (8'' <b>&#x00d7;</b> 8'') images. Some of the HST images are integrated. The filter name is presented at the top. Bottom: HST and Spitzer photometry (black square) and the best-fit templates, where gray triangles indicate the upper limits. The sum of individual <span class=\"small-caps\">eazy</span> templates is shown in the light blue curve. The yellow shaded region is the probability distribution of the photometric redshift <em>p</em>(<em>z</em>) from the SED fit. The red line indicates the spectroscopic redshift from the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] lines at \u223c268.7 GHz. A 3.6 <em>\u03bc</em>m excess feature in <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3 is explained by the contamination of the strong [O <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]<em>\u03bb</em>5007 and H<em>\u03b2</em> lines often observed in <em>z</em> \u223c 6 galaxies (e.g., Roberts-Borsani et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib112\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib112\">2016</a>; Harikane et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib53\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib53\">2018</a>).</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjabd7ecf2\" href=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf2_lr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=px9avYzMHlVSdtVxZlQhduuKNQw%3D\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjabd7ecf2\" href=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf2_hr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=h15JDuxnTRsnv2xBbTnB0FocbG8%3D\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>We conduct optical\u2013NIR photometry and spectral energy distribution (SED) analyses for these counterparts. We also perform aperture photometry, and summarize our results in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjabd7ect2\">2</a>. The procedure for aperture photometry is described in detail in Appendix <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecapp3\">C</a>. With the aperture photometry results, we conduct SED fitting using the <span class=\"small-caps\">eazy</span> code (Brammer et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib10\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib10\">2008</a>).<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecfn2\">\n                  33\n               </a></sup>\n                We fit the photometric flux densities and their uncertainties with linear combinations of templates derived from Brammer et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib10\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib10\">2008</a>), but adopting Flexible Stellar Population Synthesis models as their basis (Conroy et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib24\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib24\">2009</a>; Conroy &amp; Gunn <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib23\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib23\">2010</a>). We adopt the dust attenuation law of Kriek &amp; Conroy (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib72\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib72\">2013</a>) with <em>\u03b4</em> = 0 (i.e., a Calzetti et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib13\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib13\">2000</a> shape with an additional 2175 \u00c5 dust feature).</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjabd7ect2\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 2.</b>\u00a0Observed HST and IRAC Photometry of the Multiple Images of RXCJ0600-<em>z</em>6</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjabd7ect2\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ect2_lr.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=URkjCCS6Fi9tYj4vYfjXXUe%2ByOs%3D\"
