These results suggest that the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] kinematics of <em>z</em>6.3 are well reproduced by the best-fit 3D model. We confirm that an independent 3D modeling of a single exponential disk with <span class=\"small-caps\">galpak3d</span> also provides the best-fit values of the rotation velocity, the velocity dispersion, and the inclination, fully consistent within errors with the <sup>3D</sup>\n               <span class=\"small-caps\">barolo</span> results. We summarize the details of the 3D modeling and the results in Appendix <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecapp5\">E</a>.</p><p>In the middle panel, we present the velocity-weighted map of <em>z</em>6.3 in the source plane via a reconstruction performed in the same manner as in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs4-1\">4.1</a>. To understand the intrinsic picture without the beam smearing effect, here we use the best-fit intrinsic (i.e., resolution free) map obtained from <span class=\"small-caps\">galpak3d</span> for the reconstruction. In the right panel, we also show the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] radial velocity extracted from the three annuli with <sup>3D</sup>\n               <span class=\"small-caps\">barolo</span> (black circle), as well as the best-fit (black line) and the 1<em>\u03c3</em> error (gray shade) of the rotation curve in the tanh formalization obtained from <span class=\"small-caps\">galpak3d</span>. The correction of the lensing magnification is applied to the radius scale. For comparison, the spatial and velocity offsets of <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 are denoted by a red triangle in both middle and right panels. We find that <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 agrees with the velocity gradient of <em>z</em>6.3 within the errors, which is consistent with our interpretation that <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 is a sub region of RXCJ0600-<em>z</em>6. This suggests that clump <em>e</em> in the sub region of the galaxy (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs4-1\">4.1</a>) is likely to be a small star-forming region within the rotation disk of the host galaxy.</p><p>For the rotation-dominated system, we obtain a dynamical mass, <em>M</em><sub>dyn</sub>, of (3 \u00b1 1) <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>9</sup> \n               <em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub> based on an assumption of disk-like gas potential distribution, following Equation (4) in Dessauges-Zavadsky et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib29\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib29\">2020</a>):</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjabd7eceqn2\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7eceqn2.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=5lYF3PEq3NjWduq4yQljnhHK5w8%3D\" alt=\"Equation (2)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\left(\\displaystyle \\frac{{M}_{\\mathrm{dyn}}}{{M}_{\\odot }}\\right)=1.16\\times {10}^{5}{\\left(\\displaystyle \\frac{{v}_{\\mathrm{rot}}}{\\mathrm{km}{{\\rm{s}}}^{-1}}\\right)}^{2}\\left(\\displaystyle \\frac{{r}_{{\\rm{e}}}}{\\mathrm{kpc}}\\right),\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t2\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>where <em>v</em><sub>rot</sub> is the rotation velocity of the gaseous disk after inclination correction. We calculate the inclination from the axis ratio of the best-fit surface brightness profile results for the rest-frame UV continuum (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-5\">3.5</a>), assuming that the higher-resolution map provides a better constraint for the inclination. We adopt <em>r</em><sub>e</sub> and <em>v</em><sub>rot</sub> from the source plane reconstruction of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs4-1\">4.1</a>) and the <span class=\"small-caps\">galpak3d</span> results, respectively. We caution that the uncertainty of the inclination could remain at \u223c30% even in the spatially resolved analysis (e.g., Rizzo et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib111\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib111\">2020</a>), and thus the uncertainty in the above <em>M</em><sub>dyn</sub> estimate could be even larger.</p><p>Given the negligible contribution of the dark matter halo in the galactic scale, we estimate the molecular gas mass, <em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>, to be \u223c1\u20132 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>9</sup> \n               <em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub> by subtracting <em>M</em><sub>star</sub> (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-5\">3.5</a>) from <em>M</em><sub>dyn.</sub>. It is worth noting that this <em>M</em><sub>gas</sub> range agrees with another estimate, based on an empirically calibrated method, in Zanella et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib142\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib142\">2018</a>), given by</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjabd7eceqn3\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7eceqn3.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=cwACGmOKlBC1Jd7vwBF77R0ZTP0%3D\" alt=\"Equation (3)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\left(\\displaystyle \\frac{{L}_{[\\mathrm{CII}]}}{{L}_{\\odot }}\\right)={10}^{-1.28(\\pm 0.21)}\\times {\\left(\\displaystyle \\frac{{M}_{\\mathrm{gas}}}{{M}_{\\odot }}\\right)}^{0.98(\\pm 0.02)},\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t3\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>which suggests that <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn47.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=1kuD5kjv5Cp%2BcpL9CEvY5nwuBR0%3D\" alt=\"${M}_{\\mathrm{gas}}={3}_{-1}^{+2}\\times {10}^{9}\\,{M}_{\\odot }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{\\mathrm{gas}}={3}_{-1}^{+2}\\times {10}^{9}\\,{M}_{\\odot }</script></span></span>, despite the potentially large uncertainty of the inclination. These results indicate that RXCJ0600-<em>z</em>6 is a gas-rich galaxy with a high gas fraction of <em>f</em><sub>gas</sub> ( \u2261 <em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>/(<em>M</em><sub>star</sub> + <em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>)) \u223c 50%\u201380%. This is consistent with recent ALPINE results, where [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]-detected ALPINE galaxies with <em>M</em><sub>star</sub> \u223c 1 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>9</sup> \n               <em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub> have <em>f</em><sub>gas</sub> \u223c 60%\u201390% (see Figure 8 in Dessauges-Zavadsky et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib29\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib29\">2020</a>). These <em>M</em><sub>dyn</sub>, <em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>, and <em>f</em><sub>gas</sub> estimates are also listed in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjabd7ect4\">4</a>.</p><p>Note that we cannot rule out the possibility that the velocity gradient is originally caused by complex dynamics with interacting, merging galaxies. Future higher-resolution observations will confirm the smooth rotation of the disk, or break the complex dynamics down into their multiple components.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjabd7ecs4-3\" name=\"apjabd7ecs4-3\">4.3.\u00a0SFR and <em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub> Relation</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>In the left panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjabd7ecf8\">8</a>, we show the relation between SFR and <em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub> for <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3. For comparison, we also show local and high-redshift galaxy results taken from the literature (Malhotra et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib82\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib82\">2001</a>; D\u00edaz-Santos et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib33\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib33\">2013</a>; Magdis et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib79\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib79\">2014</a>; De Looze et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib27\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib27\">2014</a>; Herrera-Camus et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib59\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib59\">2015</a>; Spilker et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib124\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib124\">2016</a>; Cooke et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib25\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib25\">2018</a>; Harikane et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib52\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib52\">2020</a>; Matthee et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib85\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib85\">2019</a>; Schaerer et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib116\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib116\">2020</a>) and the <em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub>\u2013SFR relation obtained from local star-forming galaxies in De Looze et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib27\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib27\">2014</a>). The observed <em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub> of both <em>z</em>6.3 and <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 fall within the most luminous <em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub> regime among typical (e.g., SFR \u2272 100 <em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub> yr<sup>\u22121</sup>) high-<em>z</em> star-forming galaxies, demonstrating the power of the gravitational lensing. Following the correction of the lensing magnification, we find that both <em>z</em>6.3 and <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 fall slightly above, but still follow the SFR\u2013<em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub> relation of the local galaxies within the dispersion. This is consistent with recent ALMA results, in that the average SFR\u2013<em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub> relation among high-redshift star-forming galaxies at <em>z</em> \u223c 4\u20139 is well within the intrinsic dispersion of the local relation (Carniani et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib18\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib18\">2018</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib16\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib16\">2020</a>; Schaerer et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib116\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib116\">2020</a>). Given that RXCJ0600-<em>z</em>6 is consistent with being an abundant, sub-<em>L</em><sup>*</sup> galaxy at <em>z</em> = 6 (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-5\">3.5</a>), these results may suggest that the SFR\u2013<em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub> relation, defined by local galaxies, holds from the spatially resolved sub-kpc ISM to the whole scales in abundant galaxies, even up to the epoch of reionization.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjabd7ecf8\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjabd7ecf8\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf8_lr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=ctneH00LIM0dSu68YvZnSaKTt1k%3D\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 8.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 8.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf8_lr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=ctneH00LIM0dSu68YvZnSaKTt1k%3D\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 8.</strong>\u00a0Left: <em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub>\u2013SFR relation. The red filled and open circles indicate <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3 before and after the correction of the lensing magnification, respectively. The errors include the uncertainty from the mass models (see Table <a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjabd7ect3\">3</a>). The red open squares indicate the SFR estimates after the correction of the lensing magnification, based on the conversion from the UV and FIR luminosity of Bell et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib4\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib4\">2005</a>), scaled to the Chabrier IMF. The previous results from local to high-<em>z</em> star-forming galaxies are shown with black circles (local LIRGs; D\u00edaz-Santos et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib33\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib33\">2013</a>), black squares (local dwarfs; De Looze et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib27\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib27\">2014</a>), black triangles (local spirals; Malhotra et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib82\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib82\">2001</a>), black inverse triangles (<em>z</em> \u223c 0.3 (U)LIRGs; Magdis et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib79\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib79\">2014</a>), green circles (<em>z</em> \u223c 4\u20136 star-forming galaxies from ALPINE; Schaerer et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib116\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib116\">2020</a>), magenta pentagons (<em>z</em> \u223c 5 submillimeter galaxies (SMGs); Cooke et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib25\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib25\">2018</a>), magenta circles (<em>z</em> \u223c 2\u20136 lensed SMGs; Spilker et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib124\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib124\">2016</a>), and blue squares (compilation of recent ALMA results for <em>z</em> &gt; 5 star-forming galaxies; Matthee et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib87\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib87\">2020</a> and Harikane et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib52\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib52\">2020</a>). We adopt the average relation of the low-<em>z</em> H<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>-galaxy/starburst sample from De Looze et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib27\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib27\">2014</a>), which is adjusted to the Chabrier IMF by reducing the SFR by a factor of 1.06, in the same manner as Schaerer et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib116\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib116\">2020</a>). The arrow indicates the 3<em>\u03c3</em> upper limit. The <em>L</em><sub>FIR</sub> value in the literature is first converted into a total IR luminosity, <em>L</em><sub>TIR</sub> (8\u20131000 <em>\u03bc</em>m), and we then calculate the SFR using the calibration of Murphy et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib91\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib91\">2011</a>). The spatially resolved results (\u03a3SFR and \u03a3<em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub>) for local galaxies are also presented, indicated by open triangles (Herrera-Camus et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib59\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib59\">2015</a>), assuming an area of 1 kpc<sup>2</sup>. The dashed line and gray shading denote the <em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub>\u2013SFR relation obtained from local star-forming galaxies (De Looze et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib27\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib27\">2014</a>) and its dispersion, respectively. Right: <em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub>/SFR\u2013\u03a3SFR relation. The color assignments on the symbols are the same as those in the left panel. We define the star-forming area as a circular area of the rest-frame UV emission with a radius of <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn48.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=4KvclkYdWsBJk0KfvBVFzj9HrGE%3D\" alt=\"$\\sqrt{2}\\times {r}_{{\\rm{e}},\\mathrm{circ}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sqrt{2}\\times {r}_{{\\rm{e}},\\mathrm{circ}}</script></span></span> for the \u03a3 SFR estimate. We use a factor of <span class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn49.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=cCUnVdoyPTwSCz1E51sbjKFrck4%3D\" alt=\"$\\sqrt{2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\sqrt{2}</script></span></span> in accordance with Spilker et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib124\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib124\">2016</a>). For <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3, we evaluate the rest-frame UV size by reducing the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] size measurements from <span class=\"small-caps\">imfit</span> (Table <a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjabd7ect1\">1</a>) by a factor of 2 (see Section <a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs4-1\">4.1</a>). For the ALPINE sources, we use the rest-frame UV size measurement results from Fujimoto et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib44\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib44\">2020b</a>). For local LIRGs and lensed SMGs, we use the rest-frame FIR size measurement results from Spilker et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib124\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib124\">2016</a>), assuming that the star-forming activity dominates in the rest-frame FIR-emitting regions in these objects.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjabd7ecf8\" href=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf8_lr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=ctneH00LIM0dSu68YvZnSaKTt1k%3D\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjabd7ecf8\" href=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf8_hr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=XDT8g9%2BcJejqZJws9bnINfVwCeY%3D\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>To further study the <em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub>\u2013SFR relation, the right panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjabd7ecf8\">8</a> presents the <em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub>/SFR and SFR surface density (\u03a3SFR). This relation, or another relation between <em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub>/<em>L</em><sub>FIR</sub> and <em>L</em><sub>FIR</sub> surface density (\u03a3<em>L</em><sub>FIR</sub>), are known to have tight anti-correlations, whereby the deficit of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line is explained by the high ionization state in the ISM around regions with high \u03a3SFR or \u03a3<em>L</em><sub>FIR</sub> (e.g., D\u00edaz-Santos et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib33\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib33\">2013</a>; Spilker et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib124\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib124\">2016</a>; Gullberg et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib51\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib51\">2018</a>; Ferrara et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib37\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib37\">2019</a>). Importantly, these relations are not affected by the lensing magnification, because the same magnification factor applies to all these values. We find that <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 shows a higher <em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub>/SFR ratio, while both <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3 are consistent with the trend of the anti-correlation. This indicates that the difference of \u03a3SFR causes the difference in the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line luminosity at a given SFR between <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3, which is consistent with the source plane reconstruction results in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs4-1\">4.1</a>: the faint [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]-emitting region of <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 is separated from the bright rest-frame UV clumps by \u223c1.6 kpc in the source plane, where the ionization state of the local ISM is thought to be moderate.</p><p>We note that recent ALMA observations show nondetection results for the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line from similarly star-forming galaxies at <em>z</em> \u223c 4\u20139 at the same time (see upper limits in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjabd7ecf8\">8</a>), which is indicative of the existence of galaxies whose <em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub>\u2013SFR relations are different from those of the local galaxies. Given the requirement for prior spectroscopic redshift with the Ly<em>\u03b1</em> line in most cases (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-2\">3.2</a>), these nondetections might be related to recent reports of the potential anti-correlation between <em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub>/SFR and EW<sub>Ly<em>\u03b1</em>\n               </sub> (Harikane et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib53\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib53\">2018</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib52\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib52\">2020</a>; Carniani et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib18\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib18\">2018</a>). In contrast to the most cases, RXCJ0600-<em>z</em>6 is identified in the blind survey, and its physical properties (rest-frame EW<sub>Ly<em>\u03b1</em>\n               </sub> &lt; 4.4 \u00c5) agree with the potential anti-correlation reported in Harikane et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib53\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib53\">2018</a>). Another lensed galaxy at <em>z</em> = 6.15 (Calura et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib12\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib12\">2021</a>) also follows a similar trend, with relatively large rest-frame EW<sub>Ly<em>\u03b1</em>\n               </sub> (60 \u00b1 8 \u00c5) and small <em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub>/SFR ( \u223c2 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>5</sup>). A caveat still remains, in that Schaerer et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib116\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib116\">2020</a> report a weak dependence of <em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub>/SFR on EW<sub>Ly<em>\u03b1</em>\n               </sub>. Since the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line emissivity depends on ISM properties, such as the ionization state, metallicity, and gas density (e.g., Vallini et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib135\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib135\">2015</a>), the different <em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub>\u2013SFR relations could be alternatively explained by a larger dispersion of the ISM properties in high-<em>z</em> galaxies than in local galaxies. The uncertainties of the SFR estimates might contribute to the large dispersion in high-<em>z</em> galaxies, due to assumptions regarding star formation history, the dust-attenuation curve, and the stellar population age, as discussed in Carniani et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib16\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib16\">2020</a>), and Schaerer et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib116\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib116\">2020</a>). Another recent report regarding the extended [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line morphology up to a radius of \u223c10 kpc (e.g., Fujimoto et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib42\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib42\">2019</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib44\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib44\">2020b</a>; Ginolfi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib48\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib48\">2020</a>; Novak et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib94\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib94\">2020</a>) might also be related to some of those nondetections, because the surface brightness of the extended emission is significantly decreased in relatively high-resolution maps (Carniani et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib16\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib16\">2020</a>). Based on visibility-based stacking, the secondary extended component up to the 10 kpc scale is estimated to have an average contribution to the total line luminosity of \u223c50% around star-forming galaxies (Fujimoto et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib42\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib42\">2019</a>), and \u223c20% around quasars (Novak et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib94\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib94\">2020</a>) at <em>z</em> \u223c 6. These non-negligible contributions may be significant if the request sensitivity is close to the detection limit around the 5<em>\u03c3</em> level. However, this is not the case if the carbon in the extended [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] gas is ionized, by e.g., gravitational energy in the cold stream, shock heating in the outflow and/or inflow gas, or AGN feedback, rather than photoionization powered by the star-forming regions (see e.g., Section 5 of Fujimoto et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib42\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib42\">2019</a>).</p></div><h3 id=\"apjabd7ecs4-4\" name=\"apjabd7ecs4-4\">4.4.\u00a0[C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] Luminosity Function</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>A key goal of ALCS is to constrain the number density of the line emitters. Although the complete blind line survey results with all 33 fields will be presented in a separate paper (in preparation), we can evaluate a lower limit of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] luminosity function at <em>z</em> \u223c 6 with our [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line detection from the strongly lensed LBG at <em>z</em> = 6.0719.</p><p>To do this, we first measure the effective survey area using mass models for all 33 ALCS clusters at <em>z</em> \u223c 6, constructed in the same manner as described in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-3\">3.3</a>. After the correction of the lensing magnification, we obtain an effective survey area of \u223c49 (2) arcmin<sup>2</sup> at <em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub> = 1.0 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>9</sup> (10<sup>8</sup>)  <em>L</em><sub>\u2299</sub>, assuming the line width at FWHM = 200 km s<sup>\u22121</sup>, and with a 5<em>\u03c3</em> detection limit. We then convert the effective survey area to the survey volume, based on the frequency setup in the ALCS observations covering the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line emission at <em>z</em> = 5.974\u20136.172 and 6.381\u20136.602, and derive a lower limit of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] luminosity function at <em>z</em> = 6.</p><p>In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjabd7ecf9\">9</a>, we present the number density of [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line emitters at <em>z</em> = 6, including recent [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line studies at <em>z</em> &gt; 4 (Swinbank et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib128\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib128\">2012</a>; Matsuda et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib84\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib84\">2015</a>; Yamaguchi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib140\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib140\">2017</a>; Cooke et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib25\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib25\">2018</a>; Hayatsu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib57\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib57\">2019</a>; Decarli et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib28\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib28\">2020</a>; Yan et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib141\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib141\">2020</a>). For comparison, we also present [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] luminosity functions from semi-analytical models (Popping et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib109\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib109\">2016</a>; Lagache et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib74\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib74\">2018</a>) and from the observed SFR function (SFRF; Smit et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib121\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib121\">2016</a>) of optically-selected galaxies. For the conversion from SFRF to the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] luminosity function, we adopt the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u2013SFR relation of the local star-forming galaxies as estimated in De Looze et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib27\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib27\">2014</a>). We find that our lower limit estimate is consistent with both the semi-analytical results and SFRF. Note that we do not apply any completeness corrections to our lower limit estimate. The incompleteness for strongly lensed sources with large spatial sizes is generally significant, due to its low surface brightness (e.g., Bouwens et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib8\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib8\">2017</a>; Kawamata et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib68\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib68\">2018</a>; Fujimoto et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib43\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib43\">2017</a>). Although the incompleteness largely depends on the assumption of the intrinsic source size, this may indicate that the lower limit could be placed still higher, and that the faint end of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] luminosity function might be close to SFRF. Indeed, other constraints from the recent [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line studies are also consistent with SFRF at the bright regime (<em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub> \u2273 10<sup>8.5</sup> \n               <em>L</em><sub>\u2299</sub>). Although the brightest end (<em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub> \u2273 10<sup>9.2</sup> \n               <em>L</em><sub>\u2299</sub>) of SFRF is smaller than the constraints obtained from the SMG studies (Cooke et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib25\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib25\">2018</a>), this is explained by the absence of such dusty, obscured galaxies in the SFRF, based on the optically-selected galaxies. Therefore, the constraints of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] luminosity function obtained so far are likely to be consistent with the prediction based on the local SFR\u2013<em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub> relation and the SFRF at <em>z</em> = 6.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjabd7ecf9\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjabd7ecf9\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf9_lr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=FQwuHPlEBnbKFf%2FE271ZvSlqqjU%3D\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 9.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 9.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf9_lr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=FQwuHPlEBnbKFf%2FE271ZvSlqqjU%3D\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 9.</strong>\u00a0Cumulative [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] luminosity function at <em>z</em> = 6 with recent [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line studies at <em>z</em> &gt; 4. The red circle shows the number density of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line emitter, based on our successful detection from the strongly lensed LBG with the effective survey volume of the full ALCS data cubes, composed of 33 galaxy clusters. The lower limit is estimated from the Poisson uncertainty at the single-sided confidence level of 84.13% presented in Gehrels (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib47\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib47\">1986</a>). Recent ALMA blind line survey results are indicated by the blue triangle (243 archival data cubes; Matsuda et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib84\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib84\">2015</a>), blue inverse triangle (four massive galaxy clusters; Yamaguchi et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib140\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib140\">2017</a>), blue square (ASPECS; Decarli et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib28\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib28\">2020</a>), and blue cross (SSA22; Hayatsu et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib58\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib58\">2017</a>, <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib57\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib57\">2019</a>), respectively. The green circle represents the ALPINE results (Yan et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib141\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib141\">2020</a>; Loiacono et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib77\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib77\">2021</a>). Here we show only the estimate from the serendipitous [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line detection at <em>z</em> \u223c 5, whose redshift is sufficiently separated from (i.e., not associated with) the central ALPINE targets. The magenta square and pentagon show the serendipitous [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line detection from bright SMGs at <em>z</em> \u223c 5 reported in Swinbank et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib128\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib128\">2012</a>), and Cooke et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib25\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib25\">2018</a>), respectively. The red shading indicates the current constraints based on both our results and previous results obtained to date. For comparison, we also present the semi-analytical model results (Popping et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib109\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib109\">2016</a>; Lagache et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib74\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib74\">2018</a>) and SFR function (SFRF; Smit et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib121\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib121\">2016</a>), including the dust correction based on the SMC extinction law, whose SFR value is converted into <em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub> with the local [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u2013SFR relation (De Looze et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib27\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib27\">2014</a>).</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjabd7ecf9\" href=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf9_lr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=FQwuHPlEBnbKFf%2FE271ZvSlqqjU%3D\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjabd7ecf9\" href=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf9_hr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=zUZoTNTY4DOAxhTCum5yM6SJVfQ%3D\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div><h3 id=\"apjabd7ecs4-5\" name=\"apjabd7ecs4-5\">4.5.\u00a0From ISM to Cosmic Scales</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The source plane reconstruction in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs4-1\">4.1</a> reveals the ISM structure down to a scale of a few hundred parsecs, where we find that the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line is not displaced beyond a \u223c300 pc from the rest-frame UV continuum, from the spatially resolved ISM to the whole galaxy. In Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs4-3\">4.3</a>, we find that the SFR\u2013<em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub> relations from the spatially resolved ISM to the whole galaxy are consistent with those of local galaxies. In Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs4-4\">4.4</a>, we obtain the lower limit at the faintest regime of the <em>z</em> = 6 [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] luminosity function. We find that the prediction from the <em>z</em> = 6 SFR function and the SFR\u2013<em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub> relation of the local galaxies is consistent with both our own and previous constraints on the <em>z</em> = 6 [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] luminosity function in the wide <em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub> range. Given the unbiased aspect of the ALCS survey, and indeed the representative physical properties of RXCJ0600-<em>z</em>6 among the abundant population of the low-mass regime of <em>z</em> \u223c 6 star-forming galaxies (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-5\">3.5</a>), our results may imply that the SFR\u2013<em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub> relation of local star-forming galaxies is universal for a wide range of scales, including the spatially resolved ISM, the whole region of the galaxy, and the cosmic scale.</p></div></div><h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjabd7ecs5\" name=\"apjabd7ecs5\">5.\u00a0Summary</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>In this paper, we have presented the blind detection of a multiply imaged line emitter behind the massive galaxy cluster RXCJ0600\u22122007 in the cycle-6 ALMA large project of the ALMA Lensing Cluster Survey (ALCS). The optical\u2013NIR property, together with our lens model analyses, suggest that the emission line is the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] 158 <em>\u03bc</em>m line from a Lyman-break galaxy (LBG) at <em>z</em> = 6.0719 \u00b1 0.0004 behind RXCJ0600-2007. We have studied the relation between the star formation rate (SFR) and [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line luminosity (<em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub>), the morphology, and the kinematics in the spatially resolved interstellar medium (ISM), as well as the whole scale of the LBG, and provided a lower limit at the faint-end of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] luminosity function at <em>z</em> \u223c 6, with the help of gravitational lensing magnification. The main findings of this paper are summarized as follows:</p><ul class=\"clear-list wd-inline-list\"><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">1.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">We performed a blind line search for the ALCS data cube in RXCJ0600-2007, and identified two bright lines at \u22658<em>\u03c3</em> levels at 268.682 \u00b1 0.011 GHz and 268.744 \u00b1 0.016 GHz, one of which shows a strongly lensed arc shape. Both lines have optical\u2013NIR counterparts with clear Lyman-break feature at \u223c9000 \u00c5, indicative of the lines corresponding to the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] 158 <em>\u03bc</em>m at <em>z</em> = 6.07. The optical\u2013NIR spectral energy distribution (SED) analysis shows that probability distributions of their photometric redshifts are in excellent agreement with the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line redshift, while other possible FIR lines at <em>z</em> \u223c 6 struggle to explain the luminosity ratio between the line and the continuum. We therefore conclude that these two lines are [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] lines.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">2.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">Our lens models, updated with the latest spectroscopic follow-up results with VLT/MUSE, suggest that these lines arise from a strongly magnified and multiply imaged (<em>\u03bc</em> \u2243 20\u2212160) Lyman-break galaxy (LBG) at <em>z</em> = 6.0719, with a circularized effective radius of \u223c0.8 kpc, and an intrinsic luminosity in the rest-frame UV \u223c3 times fainter (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn50.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=tKd6Fm%2BE26ZzXoRWcsxBih1ED9U%3D\" alt=\"${M}_{\\mathrm{UV}}=-{19.7}_{-0.4}^{+0.5}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{\\mathrm{UV}}=-{19.7}_{-0.4}^{+0.5}</script></span></span>) than the characteristic luminosity at this epoch. A sub-region of the LBG crosses the caustic line in the source plane and is thereby stretched into an arc over \u223c6'' in the image plane, in which the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line is also significantly detected. Our lens models also predict another two multiple images in this field. We identified the sources at the predicted positions, and found that their optical\u2013NIR colors agree with the other multiple images of the LBGs. One of these falls within the ALCS area coverage, where we detected a tentative [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line (3.0<em>\u03c3</em>) at the same frequency as the other multiple images.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">3.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">After the correction of the lensing magnification, the whole of the LBG and its sub region were characterized with an <em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub> of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn51.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=ZWsbDsxx8RxLOkBdv4SVtlo7sIc%3D\" alt=\"${1.1}_{-0.5}^{+0.7}\\times {10}^{8}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{1.1}_{-0.5}^{+0.7}\\times {10}^{8}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn52.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=PrWkIYtbMSbXooUUIep22Pxgh7A%3D\" alt=\"${0.3}_{-0.1}^{+0.1}\\times {10}^{8}\\,{L}_{\\odot }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{0.3}_{-0.1}^{+0.1}\\times {10}^{8}\\,{L}_{\\odot }</script></span></span>, an SFR of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn53.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=D88s1MHVrCf%2FKPWqeVnGFUTxwdc%3D\" alt=\"${5.4}_{-2.9}^{+4.5}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{5.4}_{-2.9}^{+4.5}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn54.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=z6Jj6BJHqDpJc8G2lQ61u6MrDCA%3D\" alt=\"${0.8}_{-0.2}^{+0.4}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{0.8}_{-0.2}^{+0.4}</script></span></span> \n                     <em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub> yr<sup>\u22121</sup>, and a stellar mass (<em>M</em><sub>star</sub>) of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn55.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=MQVgT%2B8f1DP0GX8Vi40Aj7ICLlo%3D\" alt=\"${9.6}_{-4.6}^{+6.0}\\times {10}^{8}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{9.6}_{-4.6}^{+6.0}\\times {10}^{8}</script></span></span> and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn56.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=wGaxQFYJ18zY9mL1NDP%2BW2LYPGc%3D\" alt=\"${2.6}_{-1.0}^{+0.2}\\times {10}^{8}\\,{M}_{\\odot }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{2.6}_{-1.0}^{+0.2}\\times {10}^{8}\\,{M}_{\\odot }</script></span></span>, respectively. From the whole to sub-regions of the LBG, the SFR and <em>M</em><sub>star</sub> values fall within the average relation among <em>z</em> \u223c 6 galaxies, indicating that the LBG is an abundant, representative galaxy at this epoch.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">4.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">The source plane reconstruction resolves the ISM down to \u223c100\u2013300 pc. The [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line from the whole region of the LBG is co-spatial with the rest-frame UV continuum, while the sub region of the LBG is placed \u223c1.6 kpc away from the galactic center and bright rest-frame UV clumps. The two-peak morphology observed in the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line and rest-frame FIR continuum in the arc show a \u223c1 kpc offset from the luminosity-weighted center of the sub region of the LBG, which is likely to consists of either a clumpy structure or a smooth disk, but stretched into a two-peak morphology due to perturbation from a foreground galaxy. In these two peaks, the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line and the rest-frame FIR continuum exhibit the <em>flux ratio anomaly</em> differently, which suggests that the faint [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]- and FIR-emitting regions are displaced near the caustic.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">5.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">We find that our results in both whole and sub regions of the LBG fall within the SFR\u2013<em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub> and surface density of SFR (\u03a3SFR)\u2013<em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub>/SFR relations obtained for local star-forming galaxies. The sub-region of the galaxy has a lower \u03a3SFR and a higher <em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub>/SFR value. This is consistent with the absence of the bright rest-frame UV clumps around the sub region of the LBG, located \u223c1.6 kpc away from the galactic center, where \u03a3SFR is expected to be low.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">6.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">We find that the LBG is classified as a rotation-dominated system, based on the full observed velocity gradient and the velocity dispersion of the LBG via the bright [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line emission. The 3D modeling with <sup>3D</sup>\n                     <span class=\"small-caps\">Barolo</span> and <span class=\"small-caps\">galpak3D</span> provide consistent results for the rotation kinematics that explain the spatial and velocity offsets of the sub region of the LBG. We estimate the dynamical mass of <em>M</em><sub>dyn</sub> = (3 \u00b1 1) <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>9</sup> \n                     <em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub> and obtain the gas fraction of \u223c50%\u201380%.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">7.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">We derive a lower limit on the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] luminosity function at <em>z</em> = 6, finding that it is consistent with current semi-analytical model predictions. In conjunction with previous ALMA results, we also find that constraints on the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] luminosity function at <em>z</em> = 6 obtained so far agree with the prediction of the SFR\u2013<em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub> relation of local star-forming galaxies, as well as the SFR function at <em>z</em> = 6.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">8.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\">With the blind aspect of the ALCS survey and the SFR\u2013<em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub> relations from the sub- to whole regions of the LBG, our results may imply that the local SFR\u2013<em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub> relation is universal for a wide range of scales, including the spatially resolved ISM, the whole region of the galaxy, and the cosmic scale even up to <em>z</em> = 6, which we derive in an unbiased manner.</div></li></ul><p>\n         </p></div><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>We thank the anonymous referee for the careful review and valuable comments, which improved the clarity of the paper. We thank Justin Spilker and Tanio D\u00edaz-Santos for sharing their measurements. We also thank John R. Weaver and Yuchi Harikane for useful comments on the paper, and Francesca Rizzo for helpful comments regarding the kinematic analysis.</p><p>This paper makes use of the ALMA data: ADS/JAO. ALMA #2018.1.00035.L. ALMA is a partnership of the ESO (representing its member states), NSF (USA) and NINS (Japan), together with NRC (Canada), MOST, and ASIAA (Taiwan), and KASI (Republic of Korea), in cooperation with the Republic of Chile. The Joint ALMA Observatory is operated by the ESO, AUI/NRAO, and NAOJ. This work is based on observations and archival data acquired using the Spitzer Space Telescope, which is operated by the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, under a contract with NASA, along with archival data from the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope. This research made also use of the NASA/IPAC Infrared Science Archive (IRSA), which is operated by the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, under contract with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. This work was supported in part by World Premier International Research Center Initiative (WPI Initiative), MEXT, Japan, and JSPS KAKENHI grant No. JP18K03693. S.F. acknowledges support from the European Research Council (ERC) Consolidator Grant funding scheme (project ConTExt, grant No. 648179) and Independent Research Fund Denmark grant DFF\u20137014-00017. The Cosmic Dawn Center is funded by the Danish National Research Foundation under grant No. 140. N.L. acknowledges the Kavli Foundation. G.B.C. and K.I.C. acknowledge funding from the European Research Council via the Consolidator grant ID 681627-BUILDUP. F.E.B acknowledges support from ANID grants CATA-Basal AFB-170002, FONDECYT Regular 1190818, and 1200495, and the Millennium Science Initiative ICN12_009. I.R.S. acknowledges support from STFC (ST/T000244/1). K.K. acknowledges support from the Swedish Research Council and the Knut and Alice Wallenberg Foundation.</p><p>\n            <em>Software:</em> \n            <span class=\"small-caps\">casa</span> (v5.4.0; McMullin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib88\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib88\">2007</a>), <span class=\"small-caps\">grizli</span> (Brammer et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib10\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib10\">2008</a>), <span class=\"small-caps\">dendrogram</span> (Goodman et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib50\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib50\">2009</a>), <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> (Peng et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib102\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib102\">2010</a>), <span class=\"small-caps\">eazy</span> (Brammer et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib10\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib10\">2008</a>), <span class=\"small-caps\">scarlet</span> (Melchior et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib89\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib89\">2018</a>), <sup>3D</sup> Barolo(Di Teodoro &amp; Fraternali <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib32\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib32\">2015</a>), <span class=\"small-caps\">galpak3d</span> (Bouch\u00e9 et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib7\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib7\">2015</a>), <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> (Oguri <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib97\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib97\">2010</a>), <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> (Jullo et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib67\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib67\">2007</a>), <span class=\"small-caps\">ltm</span> (Zitrin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib143\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib143\">2015</a>).</p></div><h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjabd7ecapp1\" name=\"apjabd7ecapp1\">Appendix A: MUSE Spectroscopic Catalog</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>In Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjabd7ect5\">5</a>, we summarize the spectroscopic sample from VLT/MUSE (ESO program ID 0100.A-0792, PI: A. colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">3</td></tr><tr valign=\"top\"><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">685</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">90.0359084</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\u221220.1336945</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.4190</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">2</td></tr><tr align=\"center\">9</td></tr></tbody></table><p><small><p>\n                     <strong>Note.</strong> (1) ID from the RELICS public catalog of hlsp_relics_hst_wfc3ir_rxc0600-20_multi_v1_cat.txt (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"webref\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://relics.stsci.edu/\">https://relics.stsci.edu/</a>). IDs starting with 900 are MUSE detections, with no counterpart in the aforementioned catalog. (2) Observed R.A. in degrees. (3) Observed decl. in degrees. (4) MUSE spectroscopic redshift. (5) Redshift quality flag. 2: likely, 3: secure measurement, 9: single line measurement, and 4: field stars.</p></small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/911/2/99/suppdata/apjabd7ect5_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/abd7ec\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a>Typeset images: <a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset-multiple typeset-table-img\" href=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ect5_lr.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=qnBzSLdop8Urd0Dwog4RFN0irfg%3D\" target=\"_blank\">1</a> <a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset-multiple typeset-table-img\" href=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ect5a_lr.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=IkXjjMnixxEVEcI%2F7Hh8RkEKVmY%3D\" target=\"_blank\">2</a> </span></p></div></div><h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjabd7ecapp2\" name=\"apjabd7ecapp2\">Appendix B: Two-peak Morphology in <em>z</em>6.1/6.2</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>To check the possibility that the two-peak morphology of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line in <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 is caused by noise fluctuation, boosted by the underlying diffuse emission (e.g., Hodge et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib61\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib61\">2016</a>), we perform a mock observation using the CASA <span class=\"small-caps\">simobserve</span> software toward <em>z</em>6.1/6.2, in the same manner as Fujimoto et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib41\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib41\">2020a</a>). Here we assume the single elliptical Gaussian for the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line surface brightness distribution of <em>z</em>6.1/6.2, based on the <span class=\"small-caps\">imfit</span> results in the <em>uv</em>-tapered map (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-1\">3.1</a>). We then obtain the visibility data set via <span class=\"small-caps\">simobserve,</span> and produce the natural-weighted velocity-integrated map of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line. We repeat the mock observation 1000 times to produce the map. Given a spatial offset of \u223c2<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />0, and significance levels of 8.2<em>\u03c3</em> and 5.4<em>\u03c3</em> between the two peaks in <em>z</em>6.1/6.2, we then search multiple positive peaks that are located with spatial offsets of less than 2<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5, and detected at \u22655.4<em>\u03c3</em> levels, utilizing SExtractor version 2.5.0 (Bertin &amp; Arnouts <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib5\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib5\">1996</a>). We identify 7 out of 1000 maps with multiple peaks that meet the above criteria. These results indicate that the two-peak morphology of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line in <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 might be caused by noise fluctuation, with a probability of \u223c0.7%. Note that we find that all multiple peaks identified in the 7 maps show their flux ratios to be almost identical, which is different from the two peaks observed in <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 (ratio \u223c8:5). This indicates that the close separation, as well as the flux ratio of the two peaks observed in <em>z</em>6.1/6.2, is insufficiently explained in terms of noise fluctuation. In fact, we identify only 1 out of 1000 maps with a flux ratio of multiple peaks similar to the two peaks in <em>z</em>6.1/6.2, but with a spatial offset of 4<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />7. Therefore, we conclude that the possibility of noise fluctuation is negligible in the two-peak [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line morphology of <em>z</em>6.1/6.2.</p></div><h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjabd7ecapp3\" name=\"apjabd7ecapp3\">Appendix C: Optical\u2013NIR Photometry</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>We adopt separate strategies for extracting robust photometry for the four lensed images, as described below, to account for the crowded cluster field and varying degrees of extended source morphology. In general, we model the full IRAC mosaics using a strategy similar to that of Merlin et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib90\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib90\">2015</a>), where we use image thumbnails of each source and neighbors taken from the high-resolution HST/WFC3 F160W image, together with knowledge of the WFC3 and IRAC point-spread functions (PSFs), to model the low-resolution IRAC image.</p><h3 id=\"apjabd7ecapp3-1\" name=\"apjabd7ecapp3-1\">C.1.\u00a0Images <em>z</em>6.3 and <em>z</em>6.5</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The sources of interest in these images are relatively bright and fairly well separated from their nearest bright (projected) neighbors (Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjabd7ecf1\">1</a>). We measure aperture flux densities in each of the HST filters, using fixed <em>D</em> = 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />7 apertures centered on the source of interest to define the colors. To determine the overall flux normalization, we model the source morphology of the lensed image and nearby neighbors, using the nonparametric morphological fitting code <span class=\"small-caps\">Scarlet</span> (Melchior et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib89\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib89\">2018</a>). All of the WFC3/IR images (and their PSFs) are used to constrain the <span class=\"small-caps\">Scarlet</span> morphological model. We scale all of the HST aperture measurements <em>F</em><sub><em>ap</em>,i</sub> by the aperture correction <em>F</em><sub><em>S</em>,F160W</sub>/<em>F</em><sub><em>ap</em>,F160W</sub>, where <em>F</em><sub><em>S</em>,F160W</sub> is the integral of the <span class=\"small-caps\">Scarlet</span> model evaluated in the F160W filter, and <em>F</em><sub><em>S</em>,F160W</sub> is the aperture measurement in that filter. The photometric uncertainties are measured in the same apertures on the inverse variance image in each filter. For the IRAC flux densities of these images, we subtract all modeled sources other than the source of interest, and perform aperture photometry on this cleaned image using <em>D</em> = 3<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />0 apertures, which we correct to the same \"total\" scale as for HST, using aperture corrections of 1.6 and 1.7 for channels 1 and 2, respectively, derived from a separate bright, isolated source in the field.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjabd7ecapp3-2\" name=\"apjabd7ecapp3-2\">C.2.\u00a0Extended Arc Image <em>z</em>6.1/6.2</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>This image is a highly elongated arc extending over \u22486 arcsec coincident, with a foreground compact source in the center (Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjabd7ecf1\">1</a>). Here, we model both overlapping sources in the F160W image as parametric S\u00e9rsic profiles, using <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> software (Peng et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib102\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib102\">2010</a>). For the photometry of the lensed arc and foreground image in the WFC3/IR filters, we fit for the relative normalizations of the two S\u00e9rsic components convolved with the appropriate PSFs. For IRAC, we convolve the model S\u00e9rsic profiles with the IRAC PSF and fit for the normalization of the source of interest and all neighboring sources via least-squares optimization. As for HST, the normalization of the scaled morphological components is adopted as the photometric measurement without additional aperture corrections. For the optical images where the arc is not readily visible, we measure an aperture flux density and its associated uncertainty within a large rectangle aperture of approximately 1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />2 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 3<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />0.</p><p>Note that the deblended color of the foreground object is similar to the color of cluster members, and the best-fit SED shows the photometric redshift at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn57.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=nn6LR1GfoL4qMQAbo4fIdqkbqAc%3D\" alt=\"${0.57}_{-0.17}^{+0.14}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{0.57}_{-0.17}^{+0.14}</script></span></span>, which is close to the cluster redshift at <em>z</em> = 0.43 (see also Laporte et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib144\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib144\">2021</a>). Although this suggests the foreground to be one of the cluster members, we do not include it in our fiducial mass model due to potential systematics in the de-blending process. A detailed examination of the contribution of the foreground object to morphology and magnification factors of <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs4-1\">4.1</a>) must be investigated after we obtain the spectroscopic redshift of the foreground object.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjabd7ecapp3-3\" name=\"apjabd7ecapp3-3\">C.3.\u00a0Faint Image <em>z</em>6.4</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The final faint image of <em>z</em>6.4 is close to the cluster core and the BCG. Although it is not deblended as a separate source in our original photometric catalog (and associated IRAC model), a source is readily apparent in the F160W image (Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjabd7ecf1\">1</a>). We estimate the photometry of this image by placing fixed <em>D</em> = 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />7 and <em>D</em> = 3<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />0 apertures, centered on the F160W position in the HST and IRAC filter mosaics, respectively, and scale these measurements by the aperture corrections derived for the point sources.</p></div></div><h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjabd7ecapp4\" name=\"apjabd7ecapp4\">Appendix D: [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] Spectra of <em>z</em>6.1 and <em>z</em>6.2</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>As a sanity check of our interpretation that one of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line emitters consists of a pair of multiple images of <em>z</em>6.1 and <em>z</em>6.2, we compare the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] spectra of <em>z</em>6.1 and <em>z</em>6.2. In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjabd7ecf10\">10</a>, we show the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] spectra of <em>z</em>6.1 (red line) and <em>z</em>6.2 (blue line), normalized to the peak of <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 (black line). We find that <em>z</em>6.1 and <em>z</em>6.2 have [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line profiles consistent with each other within the errors, which agrees with our interpretation of <em>z</em>6.1 and <em>z</em>6.2 being a pair of multiple images.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjabd7ecf10\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjabd7ecf10\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf10_lr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=53ihZpAQCxTbEqC4183Yv8PADtM%3D\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 10.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 10.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf10_lr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=53ihZpAQCxTbEqC4183Yv8PADtM%3D\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 10.</strong>\u00a0Zoomed-in [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line spectra of <em>z</em>6.1 and <em>z</em>6.2 as a function of velocity with respect to the frequency peak of <em>z</em>6.3. The inset panel shows the same image cutout as the middle panel of Figure <a href=\"#apjabd7ecf1\">1</a> for <em>z</em>6.1/6.2. The red and blue squares denote apertures that are used to produce the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] spectra for <em>z</em>6.1 and <em>z</em>6.2, respectively. The black line and the gray shade indicate the integrated [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line spectrum of <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]-detected channels, respectively. The red and blue lines present the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] spectra for <em>z</em>6.1 and <em>z</em>6.2, respectively, normalized to the peak of the integrated spectrum.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjabd7ecf10\" href=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf10_lr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=53ihZpAQCxTbEqC4183Yv8PADtM%3D\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjabd7ecf10\" href=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf10_hr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=wP%2FkXjaA4ASswjon99LQO2Fwg8s%3D\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div><h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjabd7ecapp5\" name=\"apjabd7ecapp5\">Appendix E: [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] Rotation Modeling</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>In Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs4-2\">4.2</a>, we find that <em>z</em>6.3 is likely a rotation-dominated system. In Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjabd7ect6\">6</a>, we summarize the 3D modeling results for the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line around <em>z</em>6.3 from <sup>3D</sup>\n               <span class=\"small-caps\">barolo</span> (Di Teodoro &amp; Fraternali <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib32\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib32\">2015</a>) and <span class=\"small-caps\">galpak3d</span> (Bouch\u00e9 et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib7\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib7\">2015</a>). For <sup>3D</sup>\n               <span class=\"small-caps\">barolo</span>, since the ALMA beam has a half-width-at-half-maximum (HWHM) of \u223c 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />45 at the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line frequency along the orientation of the velocity gradient, we adopt three (\u223c1.4/0.45) annuli with widths of 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />45 for the tilted ring fitting algorithm. We use the THRESHOLD mask with a 2<em>\u03c3</em> limit for the data cube, and the spatial center, systemic velocity, rotation velocity (<em>v</em><sub>rot</sub>), velocity dispersion (<em>\u03c3</em><sub>vel</sub>), position angle (PA), and inclination (incl.) are used as free parameters in the fitting. The errors are estimated based on the minimization algorithm in a Monte Carlo approach. For <span class=\"small-caps\">galpak3d</span>, we adopt the exponential disk for the flux profile, the Gaussian for the thickness profile, and the <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn58.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=iLtotYuszZnoM7znTdCkyoKYl0c%3D\" alt=\"$\\tanh $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\tanh</script></span></span> formalization of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn59.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=8I9GwPG11NZtE0MsfDV5OD2a%2FTI%3D\" alt=\"${V}_{\\max }\\times \\tanh (r/{r}_{{\\rm{V}}})$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{V}_{\\max }\\times \\tanh (r/{r}_{{\\rm{V}}})</script></span></span> for the rotation curve, where <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn60.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=bvgc4UCAjZ9TG4AsTyN6GZxW6LI%3D\" alt=\"${V}_{\\max }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{V}_{\\max }</script></span></span> and <em>r</em><sub>V</sub> are the maximum velocity and the turnover radius, respectively. In place of the mask, we use a cutout data cube of 3<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />8 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 3<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />8 and [\u2212120: +120] km s<sup>\u22121</sup> for the fitting. We set a maximum iteration number of 20,000. The spatial center, systemic velocity, flux, <em>r</em><sub>e</sub>, PA, incl., <em>r</em><sub>V</sub>, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn61.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=tRGajnpECX5fWHQH3cAGossGmhM%3D\" alt=\"${V}_{\\max }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{V}_{\\max }</script></span></span>, and <em>\u03c3</em><sub>vel</sub> are used as free parameters. The errors are evaluated based on a Markov chain Monte Carlo approach.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjabd7ect6\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 6.</b>\u00a03D
