align=\"left\">\n                           <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 (arc)</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">&lt;0.07</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.32 \u00b1 0.04</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1.17 \u00b1 0.07</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1.41 \u00b1 0.13</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1.42 \u00b1 0.11</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1.34 \u00b1 0.07</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">8.18 \u00b1 0.42</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">6.02 \u00b1 0.34</td></tr><tr valign=\"top\"><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">\n                           <em>z</em>6.3</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.05 \u00b1 0.02</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.27 \u00b1 0.02</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.99 \u00b1 0.03</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1.18 \u00b1 0.06</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1.17 \u00b1 0.05</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1.19 \u00b1 0.03</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">5.46 \u00b1 0.20</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">4.17 \u00b1 0.17</td></tr><tr valign=\"top\"><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">\n                           <em>z</em>6.4</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">&lt;0.02</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.07 \u00b1 0.02</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.13 \u00b1 0.03</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.14 \u00b1 0.05</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.17 \u00b1 0.04</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.13 \u00b1 0.03</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">&lt;0.59</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">&lt;0.46<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjabd7ect2fna\">\n                              a\n                           </a></sup>\n                        </td></tr><tr valign=\"top\"><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">\n                           <em>z</em>6.5</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">&lt;0.02</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.19 \u00b1 0.02</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.51 \u00b1 0.03</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.63 \u00b1 0.05</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.66 \u00b1 0.04</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.68 \u00b1 0.03</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.40 \u00b1 0.18</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.50 \u00b1 0.15</td></tr></tbody></table><p><small><p>\n                     <strong>Note.</strong> The photometry is performed with separate strategies for four lensed images to account for the crowded cluster field and varying degrees of extended source morphology (see Appendix <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecapp3\">C</a>). For nondetection, we list the upper limit at the 2<em>\u03c3</em> level.</p><a name=\"apjabd7ect2fna\" id=\"apjabd7ect2fna\"></a><sup> \n                        a\n                     </sup>We obtain 0.34 \u00b1 0.23 <em>\u03bc</em>Jy which we replace the 2<em>\u03c3</em> upper limit.</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/911/2/99/suppdata/apjabd7ect2_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/abd7ec\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ect2_lr.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=URkjCCS6Fi9tYj4vYfjXXUe%2ByOs%3D\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjabd7ecf2\">2</a>, we show probability distributions of photometric redshifts for the optical\u2013NIR counterparts of <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3. We find that <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3 each have peak probabilities close to <em>z</em> = 6.0, in excellent agreement with the bright-line detection at \u223c268.7 GHz if the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] 158 <em>\u03bc</em>m line is at <em>z</em> = 6.07. In this case, observed line luminosities, <em>L</em><sub>line</sub> (i.e., without the correction of the lensing magnification), are estimated to be 4.5 \u00b1 0.4 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>9</sup> \n               <em>L</em><sub>\u2299</sub> and 2.3 \u00b1 0.2 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>9</sup> \n               <em>L</em><sub>\u2299</sub> for <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3, respectively. With a standard modified blackbody at <em>z</em> = 6, with a peak dust temperature <em>T</em><sub>d</sub> = 38 K (e.g., Faisst et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib36\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib36\">2020</a>), and a dust emissivity index <em>\u03b2</em><sub>d</sub> = 1.8 (e.g., Chapin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib21\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib21\">2009</a>; Planck Collaboration et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib108\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib108\">2011</a>), we also obtain observed values for rest-frame FIR luminosities, <em>L</em><sub>FIR</sub>, of 5.8 \u00b1 1.3 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>11</sup> \n               <em>L</em><sub>\u2299</sub> and 3.3 \u00b1 1.3 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>11</sup> \n               <em>L</em><sub>\u2299</sub>, and subsequently obtsin line to rest-frame FIR luminosity ratios of 7.8 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>\u22123</sup> and 6.8 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>\u22123</sup> for <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3, respectively. These ratios are consistent with the typical range of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line <em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub> and <em>L</em><sub>FIR</sub> ratios (<em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub>/<em>L</em><sub>FIR</sub>) among local galaxies (e.g., Brauher et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib11\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib11\">2008</a>; D\u00edaz-Santos et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib33\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib33\">2013</a>), which also supports the hypothesis of the bright lines at \u223c268.7 GHz being the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line. Based on the source redshift at <em>z</em> = 6.07, we also confirm that star formation rate (SFR) estimates are consistent, between the SED fitting with the dust-attenuation correction and the summation of the rest-frame UV (<em>L</em><sub>UV</sub>)and <em>L</em><sub>FIR</sub>, following the work of Bell et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib4\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib4\">2005</a>), and scaled to the Chabrier IMF:</p><div xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"display-eqn\" id=\"apjabd7eceqn1\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7eceqn1.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=Vm1j%2BlLi8yk2JgjXNnjgAWnWOFA%3D\" alt=\"Equation (1)\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex; mode=display\">\\begin{eqnarray}&&\\mathrm{SFR}\\,[{M}_{\\odot }\\,{\\mathrm{yr}}^{-1}]=1.09\\times {10}^{-10}({L}_{\\mathrm{FIR}}+2.2{L}_{\\mathrm{UV}}).\\end{eqnarray}\n\t\t\t\t\\tag{\n\t\t\t\t1\n\t\t\t\t}\n\t\t\t</script></span></div><p>\n            </p><p>Although the <em>z</em>6.3 solution shows a small non-zero probability of being at <em>z</em> \u223c 1, we also identify a 3.6 <em>\u03bc</em>m excess feature in both <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3 which is often observed in <em>z</em> \u223c 6 galaxies, due to the contamination of the strong [O <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]<em>\u03bb</em>5007 and H<em>\u03b2</em> lines (e.g., Roberts-Borsani et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib112\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib112\">2016</a>; Harikane et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib53\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib53\">2018</a>). Therefore, the high-<em>z</em> solution at <em>z</em> \u223c 6 is likely to be favored. Other possibilities for the bright line, along with the high-<em>z</em> solution, might be CO(16-15) at <em>z</em> = 5.85, and CO(17-16) at <em>z</em> = 6.28. However, recent ALMA studies derive constraints on ratios of <em>L</em><sub>CO(16\u221215)</sub>/<em>L</em><sub>FIR</sub> and <em>L</em><sub>CO(17\u221216)</sub>/<em>L</em><sub>FIR</sub> \u2272 3 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>\u22124</sup> among luminous quasars at similar redshifts (Carniani et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib17\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib17\">2019</a>). This indicates that <em>L</em><sub>line</sub>/<em>L</em><sub>FIR</sub> of <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3 are nearly 1.5 dex higher than the typical range, which argues strongly against the possibility of CO(16-15) and CO(17-16) lines. We thus conclude that <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3 are [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line emitters at <em>z</em> = 6.07. Note that we confirm that the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line solution is further supported by the lens models, intrinsic physical properties (see Sections <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-4\">3.4</a> and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-5\">3.5</a>), and follow-up Gemini/GMOS spectroscopy (Laporte et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib144\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib144\">2021</a>).</p><p>Based on the redshift of <em>z</em> = 6.07, we also examine the Ly<em>\u03b1</em> line in the MUSE data cube around <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3. We do not identify any Ly<em>\u03b1</em> features around either <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 or <em>z</em>6.3. With the rest-frame UV luminosity, this provides 3<em>\u03c3</em> upper limits for the Ly<em>\u03b1</em> equivalent width (EW<sub>Ly<em>\u03b1</em>\n               </sub>) at 4.4 \u00c5 and 3.7 \u00c5 for <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3, respectively. Given the dust continuum detection and the redshift, the absence of the bright Ly<em>\u03b1</em> line would be ascribed to dust and/or neutral hydrogen in interstellar and intergalactic media. This emphasizes the importance of the ALMA blind line search, which facilitates studies of galaxies irrespective of their Ly<em>\u03b1</em> line properties, in particular in the epoch of reionization.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjabd7ecs3-3\" name=\"apjabd7ecs3-3\">3.3.\u00a0Mass Model</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>To study the intrinsic physical properties of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line emitters <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3, we construct several mass models for the galaxy cluster RXCJ0600-2007 (<em>z</em> = 0.430) using independent algorithms, including <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> (Oguri <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib97\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib97\">2010</a>), <span class=\"small-caps\">Lenstool</span> (Jullo et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib67\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib67\">2007</a>), and Light-Traces-Mass (LTM; Zitrin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib143\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib143\">2015</a>). Multiple images are selected based on the morphology and colors of galaxies in the HST images captured using RELICS, and guided by y mass models. These models also exploit the MUSE spectroscopic redshift catalog (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs2-2\">2.2</a>) for redshift information relating to some multiple image systems, as well as secure identifications of cluster member galaxies. These models adopt nearly identical sets of multiple image systems to construct their mass models, and provide almost consistent predictions for multiple image positions and magnification factors. A brief summary of these mass models is also presented in Laporte et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib144\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib144\">2021</a>), while full details will be given in a separate paper (in preparation). In this paper, we adopt the mass model of <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> as a fiducial model for our analyses; its construction is described below, although we also use results of <span class=\"small-caps\">Lenstool</span> and LTM models to evaluate uncertainties in magnification factors.</p><p>We construct a mass model using <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic,</span> in the same manner as Kawamata et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib69\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib69\">2016</a>). Our mass model consists of cluster-scale halos and cluster member galaxies. We place the cluster-scale halos at the positions of the three brightest cluster member galaxies in the core of the cluster. The position of one of the three cluster-scale halos is treated as a free parameter, whereas those of the other two cluster-scale halos are fixed to the galaxy positions. The cluster-scale halos are modeled via an elliptical Navarro\u2013Frenk\u2013White (NFW; e.g., Navarro et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib92\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib92\">1997</a>) profile. The cluster member galaxies are selected using photometric redshifts of galaxies measured from HST images (Coe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib22\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib22\">2019</a>) together with galaxy colors. The position and shapes of the member galaxies are fixed to those derived from the HST image, and treat their velocity dispersions and truncation radii using a pseudo-Jaffe ellipsoid as model parameters, assuming a scaling relation (see Kawamata et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib69\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib69\">2016</a>, for more details). In order to achieve a good fit, a member galaxy located at (R.A., decl.) = (06:00:10.664, \u221220:06:50.65) that produces multiple images is treated as a separate component, again assuming a pseudo-Jaffe ellipsoid. An external shear term, which provides a modest improvement in the mass modeling result, is also included in the mass modeling of this cluster. Having included the multiple images presented in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-4\">3.4</a>, confirmed with help of our preliminary mass models, we have the positions of 26 multiple images for eight sets of multiple image systems (five multiple image sets with spectroscopic redshifts) that we then adopt as constraints. We optimize the parameters of the mass model based on a standard <em>\u03c7</em><sup>2</sup> minimization, and determine the best-fit mass model, assuming a positional error of 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />6 for each multiple image to account for perturbations by substructures in the cluster that are not included in our mass model, and estimate the statistical error using the Markov chain Monte Carlo method. Our best fitting model has <em>\u03c7</em><sup>2</sup> = 20.0 for 17 degrees of freedom. Interested readers are referred to Kawamata et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib69\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib69\">2016</a>) for more specific mass modeling procedures using <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span>.</p><p>Note that we do not include the foreground object overlapping <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 in our mass models, owing to the absence of its spectroscopic redshift. We will discuss the potential contribution of the foreground object to the morphology and magnification factor of <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs4-1\">4.1</a>.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjabd7ecs3-4\" name=\"apjabd7ecs3-4\">3.4.\u00a0Multiple Images</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>From all of our mass models, we consistently obtain the following two predictions: (i) <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 consists of a pair of multiple images of a galaxy at <em>z</em> \u223c 6 behind RXCJ0600-2007, and (ii) <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3 are also multiple images of the galaxy. The prediction of (ii) is consistent with the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] morphology with two close peaks. In fact, we confirm in Appendix <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecapp4\">D</a> that [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line spectra produced at these two peaks show line profiles consistent with each other. In addition, almost the same optical\u2013NIR SED shapes between <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3 in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjabd7ecf2\">2</a> support the prediction of (ii). Although we identify the slight velocity shift between <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3 by 69 \u00b1 22 km s<sup>\u22121</sup> (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-1\">3.1</a>), the offset is much smaller than the typical FWHM range of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line among <em>z</em> \u223c 4\u20136 galaxies evaluated in the ALPINE survey (\u223c120\u2013380 km s<sup>\u22121</sup>; B\u00e9thermin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib6\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib6\">2020</a>), suggesting that the slight velocity shift is explained by the differential magnification at different regions of the galaxy. We thus interpret <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3 as multiple images of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line emission at <em>z</em> = 6.07 from a Lyman-break galaxy (LBG) behind RXCJ0600-2007. Hereafter we refer to the background LBG as RXCJ0600-<em>z</em>6.</p><p>Subsequently, the different models also predict two additional multiple images of RXCJ0600-<em>z</em>6, the positions of which we present in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjabd7ecf1\">1</a>, where we identify corresponding optical\u2013NIR objects. We refer to these potential multiple images as <em>z</em>6.4 and <em>z</em>6.5. Note that different mass models predict a consistent position for <em>z</em>6.4, while predicting different positions for <em>z</em>6.5, with a scatter in a \u223c12'' scale. In this paper, we focus an optical\u2013NIR object as <em>z</em>6.5, as predicted by one of our mass models, but this should be regarded as tentative, as we will discuss below.</p><p>To investigate whether the multi-wavelength properties of these potential multiple images are similar to <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3, we conduct aperture photometry for <em>z</em>6.4 and <em>z</em>6.5 in the optical\u2013NIR bands. The detailed procedure for aperture photometry is again described in Appendix <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecapp3\">C</a>. In Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjabd7ect2\">2</a> and Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjabd7ecf3\">3</a>, we summarize the photometry results and the optical\u2013NIR colors normalized by the photometry at the F125W band, respectively. We find that <em>z</em>6.4 and <em>z</em>6.5 have similar optical\u2013NIR SEDs with <em>z</em>6.1/6.2, <em>z</em>6.3 within the errors, consistent with our mass model predictions as multiple images at <em>z</em> \u223c 6. We further perform the optical\u2013NIR SED fitting to <em>z</em>6.4 and <em>z</em>6.5 in the same manner as <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3. In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjabd7ecf2\">2</a>, we also show the optical\u2013NIR SED fitting results of <em>z</em>6.4 and <em>z</em>6.5. While the <em>z</em>6.4 photometry also allows for a <em>z</em> \u223c 6 solution, the possibility of much lower redshifts cannot be excluded, given the large uncertainties due to its faint characteristics, as well as potential contamination from the nearby BCG (see Appendix <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecapp3-3\">C.3</a>). <em>z</em>6.5 has a well-localized peak probability at <em>z</em> \u223c 6, although the HST\u2013Spitzer color of <em>z</em>6.5 is much bluer than that seen for the bright images <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3. In fact, an IRAC source at the location of <em>z</em>6.5 should be easily detected if it has the same color as those of the other images.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjabd7ecf3\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjabd7ecf3\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf3_lr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=oHY86CmlFlWZ7ESdR8q1Ois4x5U%3D\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 3.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 3.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf3_lr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=oHY86CmlFlWZ7ESdR8q1Ois4x5U%3D\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 3.</strong>\u00a0Observed SEDs of the multiple images of RXCJ0600-<em>z</em>6 in the HST bands, normalized by the F125W band. The green, red, brown, and blue squares represent <em>z</em>6.1/6.2, <em>z</em>6.3, <em>z</em>6.4, and <em>z</em>6.5, respectively.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjabd7ecf3\" href=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf3_lr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=oHY86CmlFlWZ7ESdR8q1Ois4x5U%3D\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjabd7ecf3\" href=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf3_hr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=RrLOk4qTtirR0M3W9lS1M8V2Vyg%3D\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>Given that <em>z</em>6.4 falls in the ALCS area coverage, we also examine whether the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line emission is detected from <em>z</em>6.4 at a frequency consistent with <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3. In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjabd7ecf1\">1</a>, we also show the ALMA Band 6 spectrum of <em>z</em>6.4, based on an optimized aperture with a radius of 1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5. We find that <em>z</em>6.4 has a tentative line detection (3.0<em>\u03c3</em>) at a frequency consistent with <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3. Moreover, <em>z</em>6.4 has an asymmetry line profile (the brighter peak at the higher frequency side) which is consistent with the line profile of <em>z</em>6.3. These results strengthen the case that <em>z</em>6.4 is indeed one of the multiple images of the background LBG.</p><p>Based on these results, we find that the identification of <em>z</em>6.4 as one of the multiple images is relatively secure in terms of the consistent predictions of the mass models, as well as the line detection at the consistent frequency. On the other hand, based on the different predicted positions among the different mass models, and the disagreements in the HST\u2013Spitzer color with other multiple images, the interpretation of <em>z</em>6.5 being another multiple image is not secure, and should be taken with caution until a spectroscopic redshift is obtained in follow-up observations. We therefore use the positions of <em>z</em>6.1/6.2, <em>z</em>6.3, and <em>z</em>6.4 as constraints in deriving our best-fit mass models. We present the critical curve at <em>z</em> = 6.07 from the best-fit mass model of <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> in the left panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjabd7ecf1\">1</a>. We summarize the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line properties and the SED fitting results for all these multiple images in Tables <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjabd7ect1\">1</a> and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjabd7ect3\">3</a>, respectively.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjabd7ect3\" align=\"center\">\u22ef</td></tr></tbody></table><p><small><p>\n                     <strong>Note.</strong> Physical properties obtained from the SED fitting of the observed photometry with <span class=\"small-caps\">eazy</span> without correcting for the lensing magnification. The intrinsic physical properties after the correction of the lensing magnification are summarized in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjabd7ect4\">4</a>. Based on the conversion from the UV and FIR luminosity of Bell et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib4\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib4\">2005</a>), scaled to the Chabrier IMF, we obtain consistent SFR estimates of 188 \u00b1 15 <em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub> yr<sup>\u22121</sup> and 120 \u00b1 14 <em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub> yr<sup>\u22121</sup> for <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3, respectively. Since UV luminosity dominates in both <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3, a \u00b1 10 K difference in the <em>T</em><sub>d</sub> assumption for the <em>L</em><sub>FIR</sub> calculation (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-2\">3.2</a>) changes these SFR estimates by \u223c0.1 dex.</p><a name=\"apjabd7ect3fna\" id=\"apjabd7ect3fna\"></a><sup> \n                        a\n                     </sup>We define <em>\u03bc</em><sub>whole</sub> and <em>\u03bc</em><sub>local</sub> as follows: <em>\u03bc</em><sub>whole</sub> = (observed luminosity of the multiple image)/(overall luminosity of the intrinsic galaxy); <em>\u03bc</em><sub>local</sub> = (observed luminosity of the multiple image)/(local luminosity of the strongly lensed, sub region near the caustic line), where the sub region corresponds to the dashed rectangle area in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjabd7ecf4\">4</a>. The errors are evaluated on the basis of the minimum to maximum range among our independent mass models.</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/911/2/99/suppdata/apjabd7ect3_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/abd7ec\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ect3_lr.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=C5ajzbgYD%2F8OoUM3bC3%2FaLq7frc%3D\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div></div><h3 id=\"apjabd7ecs3-5\" name=\"apjabd7ecs3-5\">3.5.\u00a0Physical Properties of RXCJ0600-<em>z</em>6</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The configuration of the multiple images is helpful in obtaining precise information about the source position and its surface brightness profile in the source plane. Here we estimate the intrinsic two-dimensional (2D) surface brightness profile by fitting the HST images, assuming the fiducial mass model. Specifically, we first produce a 1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />7 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />7 cutout HST/F160W image of <em>z</em>6.3. With a single S\u00e9rsic profile model in the source plane, we then obtain a best-fit effective radius of <em>r</em><sub>e</sub> = <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn24.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=IaruMyKJANohNXpCB5CiH%2FozsPU%3D\" alt=\"${1.2}_{-0.1}^{+4.1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{1.2}_{-0.1}^{+4.1}</script></span></span> kpc (major axis), an axis ratio of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn25.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=Rp%2BobOkQqBUes4DeKNnnwS0zuXw%3D\" alt=\"${0.49}_{-0.02}^{+0.03}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{0.49}_{-0.02}^{+0.03}</script></span></span>, a position angle = <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn26.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=WjkjAGXWS3ub34huBP38Io2wcnM%3D\" alt=\"${84}_{-2}^{+2\\circ }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{84}_{-2}^{+2\\circ }</script></span></span>, a S\u00e9rsic index of <em>n</em> = <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn27.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=jqGgHAvpBcTRf%2BG%2FK6IZCUrk7Kk%3D\" alt=\"${2.5}_{-0.1}^{+1.2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{2.5}_{-0.1}^{+1.2}</script></span></span>, and a central coordinate of (R.A., decl.) = (6:00:08.12, \u221220:07:39.55), based on standard <em>\u03c7</em><sup>2</sup> minimization. Since we find a degeneracy between <em>r</em><sub>e</sub> and <em>n</em>, we restrict the S\u00e9rsic index to the range of 1 &lt; <em>n</em> &lt; 4 in the fitting in this case. We do not use <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.4 for the fitting, due to the complicated morphology, and to the contamination of the diffuse emission from the nearby BCG, respectively. We ignore the clumpy structure of <em>z</em>6.3 for the moment, and reserve it for later discussion. We list these best-fit S\u00e9rsic profile results in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjabd7ect4\">4</a>.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjabd7ect4\" alt=\"${0.07}_{-0.05}^{+0.11}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{0.07}_{-0.05}^{+0.11}</script></span></span>\n                        </td></tr><tr valign=\"top\"><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">\n                           <em>r</em><sub>e</sub> (kpc)</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1.2 <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn39.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=R8lpQU0DLvZsj%2FOiegZUoEE%2FA7E%3D\" align=\"center\">\n                           <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn40.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=HxQXKiGWHklQ1iNFWkzz4s%2FoRyQ%3D\" align=\"center\">\u22ef</td></tr><tr valign=\"top\"><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">axis ratio</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\n                           <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn41.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=W2iIASy14rYkZaSNxOELGnd25sU%3D\" alt=\"${0.49}_{-0.02}^{+0.03}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{0.49}_{-0.02}^{+0.03}</script></span></span>\n                        </td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\u22ef</td></tr><tr valign=\"top\"><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">PA (<sup>\u25e6</sup>)</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\n                           <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn42.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=x6KZ04Ylhsuqwm%2Fh6bBX64vV0j4%3D\" alt=\"${84}_{-2}^{+2}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{84}_{-2}^{+2}</script></span></span>\n                        </td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\u22ef</td></tr><tr valign=\"top\"><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">\n                           <em>M</em><sub>dyn</sub>( <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>9</sup> \n                           <em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub>)</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">3 \u00b1 1</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\u22ef</td></tr><tr valign=\"top\"><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">\n                           <em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>( <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>9</sup> \n                           <em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub>)</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">2 \u00b1 1</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\u22ef</td></tr><tr valign=\"top\"><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">\n                           <em>f</em><sub>gas</sub> (%)</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\u223c50\u201380</td><td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\u22ef</td></tr></tbody></table><p><small><p>\n                     <strong>Note.</strong> (1) The physical properties related to the whole region of the galaxy, obtained by applying <em>\u03bc</em><sub>whole</sub> (Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjabd7ect3\">3</a>) to the observed properties of <em>z</em>6.3. The best-fit S\u00e9rsic profile (<em>r</em><sub>e</sub>, <em>n</em>, and axis ratio) is not estimated by using <em>\u03bc</em><sub>whole</sub>, but by optimizing the intrinsic 2D surface brightness profile in the source plane to match the 2D surface brightness profile of <em>z</em>6.3 in the image plane via <span class=\"small-caps\">glafic</span> (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-5\">3.5</a>). The circularized effective radius is estimated to be <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn43.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=Dk7uD3MNFCeZDgOc8RMy1pc1lv4%3D\" alt=\"${0.8}_{-0.1}^{+2.9}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{0.8}_{-0.1}^{+2.9}</script></span></span> kpc, which is consistent to within \u223c1\u20132<em>\u03c3</em> errors, with an independent 2D surface brightness profile fit on the image plane in Laporte et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib144\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib144\">2021</a>). We calculate <em>M</em><sub>gas</sub> by subtracting <em>M</em><sub>star</sub> from <em>M</em><sub>dyn</sub>, which is consistent with another estimate from the empirical calibration with [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] luminosity (Zanella et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib142\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib142\">2018</a>) of 3 \u00b1 1 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 10<sup>9</sup> \n                     <em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub> (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs4-2\">4.2</a>). (2) The physical properties related to the local scale of the galaxy in the sub region near the caustic line, by applying <em>\u03bc</em><sub>local</sub> (Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjabd7ect3\">3</a>) to the observed properties of <em>z</em>6.1/6.2.</p><a name=\"apjabd7ect4fna\" id=\"apjabd7ect4fna\"></a><sup> \n                        a\n                     </sup>The sub region is redshifted by 69 \u00b1 22 km s<sup>\u22121</sup>, which agrees well with the velocity gradient identified in the whole scale of RXCJ0600-<em>z</em>6 (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs4-2\">4.2</a>).</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/911/2/99/suppdata/apjabd7ect4_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/abd7ec\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ect4_lr.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=sbng7oI1cfoiSONWcIWHneNZr9k%3D\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjabd7ecf4\">4</a>, we show the best-fit 2D S\u00e9rsic profile in the source plane, and its multiple images in the image plane. We find that a single S\u00e9rsic profile effectively reproduces not only <em>z</em>6.3, but also <em>z</em>6.4 and <em>z</em>6.1/6.2, whose elongated shape is interpreted as a result of the source crossing the caustic line in the source plane and being stretched over \u223c6'' scale in the image plane (e.g., Vanzella et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib136\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib136\">2020</a>). This interpretation is consistent with the slight difference in the line peak frequencies and the line profiles between <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3 (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-1\">3.1</a>), because the sub region of the galaxy can have different kinematic properties, as compared to the whole galaxy. By calculating the ratio of the spatial areas between the source and image planes, the magnification factors for <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3 in our fiducial model (average of the three independent models) are estimated to be \u223c150 (163) and \u223c35 (21), respectively. The observed luminosity of <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 is 33 (29) times brighter than the intrinsic overall luminosity of RXCJ0600-<em>z</em>6, due to the strong gravitational lensing effect near the caustic line. By comparing the physical properties of <em>z</em>6.3 and <em>z</em>6.4 that trace the whole region of the lensed galaxy, we confirm that our independent mass models agree in the ratio of magnification factors between <em>z</em>6.3 and <em>z</em>6.4 in the range of 6.1\u20136.7, which is consistent with the observed <em>L</em><sub>[CII]</sub> ratio of 5.7 \u00b1 2.7 between <em>z</em>6.3 and <em>z</em>6.4. These results validates our best-fit mass models and 2D S\u00e9rsic profile in the source plane.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjabd7ecf4\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjabd7ecf4\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf4_lr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=3iWfyt2dUw9iQMGDPFbkim0nt5U%3D\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 4.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 4.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf4_lr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=3iWfyt2dUw9iQMGDPFbkim0nt5U%3D\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 4.</strong>\u00a0Left: best-fit 2D S\u00e9rsic profile (effective radius in major axis = 1.2 kpc, axis ratio = 0.49, S\u00e9rsic index <em>n</em> = 2.5) and coordinate (R.A., decl. = 6:00:08.12, \u221220:07:39.55) of the lensed LBG RXCJ0600-<em>z</em>6 at <em>z</em> = 6.0719 in the source plane, based on the fiducial mass model. The fitting is performed based on the standard <em>\u03c7</em><sup>2</sup> minimization, only with the 1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />7 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />7 HST/F160W cutout of <em>z</em>6.3. The white dashed curves denote the caustic lines at the source redshift. Middle: multiple images of RXCJ0600-<em>z</em>6 in the image plane, <em>z</em>6.1/6.2, <em>z</em>6.3, and <em>z</em>6.4, as predicted by the fiducial mass model with the best-fit 2D S\u00e9rsic profile in the left panel. The black boxes show the 6'' <b>&#x00d7;</b> 6'' areas around <em>z</em>6.3 and <em>z</em>6.4 at the same positions as the yellow boxes in Figure <a href=\"#apjabd7ecf1\">1</a>. The dashed black rectangle denotes the 6'' <b>&#x00d7;</b> 17'' area around <em>z</em>6.1<em>z</em>6.2, which approximately corresponds to the dashed black rectangle shown in the left panel along the caustic line. The white line indicates the critical curve. Right: HST/F160W image, showing the multiple images of <em>z</em>6.1/6.2, <em>z</em>6.3, and <em>z</em>6.4. The image size is the same as that shown in the middle panel. The color and symbols are assigned in the same manner as the middle panel.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjabd7ecf4\" href=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf4_lr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=3iWfyt2dUw9iQMGDPFbkim0nt5U%3D\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjabd7ecf4\" href=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf4_hr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=UQKq0WiIt%2FzEhBMego7pQ1CjB%2BY%3D\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>To be conservative, we adopt the average value of the magnification factors, evaluating its uncertainty from the minimum to maximum values among our independent mass models, when we estimate the intrinsic physical properties of RXCJ0600-<em>z</em>6 in this paper. We list the average magnification factor and its uncertainty in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjabd7ect3\">3</a>. Applying the average magnification factors to the FIR (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-1\">3.1</a>) and optical\u2013NIR (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-2\">3.2</a>) properties, we summarize the intrinsic physical properties in both whole and sub-regions of RXCJ0600-<em>z</em>6 in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjabd7ect4\">4</a>. Remarkably, we obtain the intrinsic absolute rest-frame UV magnitude of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn44.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=HyGpyCDHpIYvyuhFqz2A1n2JMi8%3D\" alt=\"${M}_{\\mathrm{UV}}=-{19.75}_{-0.45}^{+0.55}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{\\mathrm{UV}}=-{19.75}_{-0.45}^{+0.55}</script></span></span>, which is \u223c3 times fainter than the <em>L</em><sup>*</sup> value of the LBG luminosity function at <em>z</em> = 6 (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn45.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=iRj%2FJXxgt5uLylEuFgOl%2B5okhn0%3D\" alt=\"${M}_{\\mathrm{UV}}={20.91}_{-0.06}^{+0.07};$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{\\mathrm{UV}}={20.91}_{-0.06}^{+0.07};</script></span></span> Ono et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib99\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib99\">2018</a>). In Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjabd7ecf5\">5</a>, we show the SFR and <em>M</em><sub>star</sub> relation of RXCJ0600-<em>z</em>6. For comparison, we also present the average relation among the <em>z</em> \u223c 6 galaxies estimated in Iyer et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib65\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib65\">2018</a>) (gray shaded region). We find that RXCJ0600-<em>z</em>6 falls on the average relation from the sub- to whole regions. We also find that the relation between the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line width and luminosity in RXCJ0600-<em>z</em>6 agrees with the average value among <em>z</em> \u223c 6 galaxies, as well as the theoretical prediction (see Figure 10 in Kohandel et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib71\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib71\">2019</a>). The circularized effective radius (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecieqn46.gif?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=v4jQrMe0tr0QGBilvrd2Q8BPj2s%3D\" alt=\"${r}_{{\\rm{e}},\\mathrm{circ}}\\equiv {r}_{{\\rm{e}}}\\times \\sqrt{\\mathrm{axis}\\,\\mathrm{ratio}}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{r}_{{\\rm{e}},\\mathrm{circ}}\\equiv {r}_{{\\rm{e}}}\\times \\sqrt{\\mathrm{axis}\\,\\mathrm{ratio}}</script></span></span>) of 0.84 kpc also falls within a typical range among <em>z</em> \u223c 6 galaxies with similar UV luminosity (see e.g., Figure 9 of Kawamata et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib68\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib68\">2018</a>). These results indicate that RXCJ0600-<em>z</em>6 is an abundant, representative sub-<em>L</em><sup>*</sup> galaxy at this epoch. We note that these intrinsic physical properties are consistent with independent estimates in Laporte et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib144\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib144\">2021</a>) within the errors, even though the SED fitting strategies are different, due to the respective scope of each paper.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjabd7ecf5\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjabd7ecf5\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf5_lr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=pR6CG5L%2BJF9%2ByJIUnGq8yifwRWc%3D\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 5.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 5.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf5_lr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=pR6CG5L%2BJF9%2ByJIUnGq8yifwRWc%3D\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 5.</strong>\u00a0SFR\u2013<em>M</em><sub>star</sub> relation. The red filled and open circles indicate the relations before and after applying the correction of the lensing magnification to the SED fitting results, respectively, for <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 and <em>z</em>6.3. The errors include the uncertainty from the mass models (Table <a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjabd7ect3\">3</a>). The red open squares indicate SFR estimates after lensing magnification correction, based on the conversion from the UV and FIR luminosity of Bell et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib4\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib4\">2005</a>), scaled to the Chabrier IMF. The black line and the gray shaded region denote the best-fit relation for <em>z</em> \u223c 6 galaxies and its 1<em>\u03c3</em> uncertainty, as evaluated in Iyer et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib65\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib65\">2018</a>).</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjabd7ecf5\" href=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf5_lr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=pR6CG5L%2BJF9%2ByJIUnGq8yifwRWc%3D\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjabd7ecf5\" href=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf5_hr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=xc4q0CuGbgdGH831Qtc2v0ZdphI%3D\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div></div><h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjabd7ecs4\" name=\"apjabd7ecs4\">4.\u00a0[C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] Views from ISM to Cosmic Scales</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>The uniquely and strongly lensed galaxy near the caustic line (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-3\">3.3</a>) allows us to study ISM properties from internal to whole scales in the host galaxy. For an example of the whole view of the galaxy based on <em>z</em>6.3, the spatial resolutions of the HST map of \u223c0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />2 translate into 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />04 (corresponding to \u223c250 pc at <em>z</em> = 6.07) after the correction of the lensing magnification, providing sub-kpc scale ISM views. At the same time, the blind aspect of the ALCS survey also allows us to statistically evaluate the number density of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line emitters at <em>z</em> \u223c 6 in a cosmic scale, based on our successful identification of RXCJ0600-<em>z</em>6. In conjunction with the rest-frame UV and FIR continuum properties, we examine the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line properties from the ISM to cosmic scales, and discuss the existence of common properties or a large diversity between these multiple scales.</p><h3 id=\"apjabd7ecs4-1\" name=\"apjabd7ecs4-1\">4.1.\u00a0Spatial Distributions of UV, FIR, and [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] Down to Sub-kpc Scale</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Making full use of gravitational lensing, we investigate the spatial distributions of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line, rest-frame UV, and FIR continuum on the source plane, and compare them. In the context of similar studies so far at <em>z</em> \u223c 2\u20134 for bright, dusty, starburst galaxies (e.g., Swinbank et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib129\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib129\">2010</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib130\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib130\">2015</a>; Dye et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib34\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib34\">2015</a>; Spilker et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib124\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib124\">2016</a>; Rybak et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib115\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib115\">2015</a>; Tamura et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib132\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib132\">2015</a>; Hatsukade et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib56\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib56\">2015</a>; Rybak et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib114\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib114\">2020</a>; Rizzo et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib111\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib111\">2020</a>), and less massive galaxies (e.g., Dessauges-Zavadsky et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib31\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib31\">2017</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib30\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib30\">2019</a>), this is a first observation to resolve the ISM structure down to the sub-kpc scale for the sub-<em>L</em><sup>*</sup> galaxy in the epoch of reionization.</p><p>In the left panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjabd7ecf6\">6</a>, we present the rest-frame UV continuum maps for <em>z</em>6.3 (i.e., whole region) and <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 (i.e., sub region) in the HST/F160W band, with the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line (red contour) and the rest-frame FIR continuum (green contour) captured by ALMA. The emission peaks of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line and rest-frame FIR continuum are marked with red and green squares (triangles) for <em>z</em>6.3 (<em>z</em>6.1/6.2), and with 1<em>\u03c3</em> error bars,<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecfn3\">\n                  34\n               </a></sup>\n                respectively. Here we do not examine the rest-frame FIR continuum peak from <em>z</em>6.3, due to its poor significance at the 2.5<em>\u03c3</em> level (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-1\">3.1</a>). In <em>z</em>6.3, the rest-frame UV continuum shows a clumpy structure, and we duly mark these clumps with black crosses labeled <em>a</em>, <em>b</em>, and <em>c</em>, from brightest to faintest. The rest-frame UV continuum of <em>z</em>6.3 also shows an elongated structure toward the north east, which we mark with an additional black cross and label <em>d</em>. In <em>z</em>6.1/6.2, possible clumps are more evident in the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line and the rest-frame FIR continuum with the two-peak morphology. If RXCJ0600-<em>z</em>6 consists of a smooth disk, the morphology of <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 would be a single smooth arc shape, as shown in the middle panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjabd7ecf4\">4</a>. Therefore, the two-peak morphology of <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 may imply that the ISM of RXCJ0600-<em>z</em>6 near the caustic line has a clumpy structure in the source plane. An alternative possibility is that an intrinsically smooth disk is stretched into the two-peak morphology in the image plane, due to perturbation from the foreground object overlapping <em>z</em>6.1/6.2, which is not included in our fiducial mass model. To check this possibility, we include the foreground object in our mass model, assuming that it is a member galaxy of the cluster (see Appendix <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecapp3-2\">C.2</a>), finding that the two-peak structure can indeed be reproduced, if the mass associated with the foreground object is comparable or larger than that expected from the scaling relation of the luminosity and mass for cluster member galaxies constrained in our mass modeling. We conclude that we need more follow-up data, including the spectroscopic redshift of the foreground object, in order to discriminate these two possibilities. We confirm, however, that both magnification factors of <em>\u03bc</em><sub>local</sub> and <em>\u03bc</em><sub>whole</sub> for <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 are affected only by \u223c1%\u20132%, even if we include the foreground object in the mass model as one of the cluster members or outside of the cluster up to <em>z</em> \u223c 4. The other foreground object near <em>z</em>6.3 is classified as one of the member galaxies of the cluster (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-2\">3.2</a>), and is predicted to produce the critical curve at the southern east part of <em>z</em>6.3 in our mass model (see the middle panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjabd7ecf4\">4</a>). However, we find that the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] morphology at the corresponding area is not disturbed at all, suggesting that its lensing effect is negligible for <em>z</em>6.3. We therefore remove this foreground object from the mass model and the HST map with <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> in the source plane reconstruction of <em>z</em>6.3.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjabd7ecf6\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjabd7ecf6\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf6_lr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=1gvrllJtU48Y6T%2B5%2Foh57eS2%2Fag%3D\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 6.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 6.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.68.1/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf6_lr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=1gvrllJtU48Y6T%2B5%2Foh57eS2%2Fag%3D\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 6.</strong>\u00a0Left: 3'' <b>&#x00d7;</b> 3'' and 6'' <b>&#x00d7;</b> 6'' HST/F160W cutouts of <em>z</em>6.3 (top) and <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 (bottom) in the image plane. The small black crosses denote bright clumps (marked <em>a</em>, <em>b</em>, and <em>c</em>) and an elongated structure toward north east (<em>d</em>) in the rest-frame UV continuum. The dashed black cross indicates the peak position of the rest-frame UV continuum after smoothing the HST map to match the resolution with ALMA. The red and green contours represent the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line and the rest-frame FIR continuum from ALMA, drawn at 1<em>\u03c3</em> intervals from 2<em>\u03c3</em> to 8<em>\u03c3</em>. The red and green squares (triangles) in <em>z</em>6.3 (<em>z</em>6.1/6.2) show the emission peak pixel positions of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line and rest-frame FIR continuum with 1<em>\u03c3</em> error bars, respectively. The cyan contours are drawn at 2<em>\u03c3</em> for the rest-frame UV continuum. The foreground galaxies are removed with <span class=\"small-caps\">galfit</span> for the purpose of source plane reconstruction. Here we use the natural-weighted map for the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line, and the <em>uv</em>-tapered maps with 2<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />0 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 2<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />0 and 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />8 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />8 for the rest-frame FIR continuum of <em>z</em>6.3 and <em>z</em>6.1/6.2, respectively. Right: source plane reconstruction of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line and rest-frame UV and FIR continuum of <em>z</em>6.3. The color and symbols follow the same assignment as the left panel, where the cyan and red contours show 10%, 30%, 50%, and 80% of the peak. To match the spatial resolutions of ALMA and HST, the red contours are drawn from the source plane reconstruction of the de-convolved [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] spatial distribution obtained with <span class=\"small-caps\">imfit</span> (Section <a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-1\">3.1</a>), and smoothed using the HST PSF. The inset panel displays the source plane reconstruction of <em>z</em>6.1/6.2. The cyan (red) contours show 1%, 3%, 5%, and 10% (10%, 30%, and 50%) of the peak of the whole galaxy, respectively. The luminosity-weighted center is marked with the label <em>e</em>, corresponding to the faint rest-frame UV clump at the western part of the whole galaxy. The white ellipses show the typical shape of the HST PSF reconstructed in the source plane. The error bars of the red square, triangle, and green triangle incorporate the average lensing magnification corrections and their uncertainties. Note that the two peaks (= triangles) in <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 in the image plane constitute a multiple pair (Section <a class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-3\">3.3</a>), which thereby correspond to one peak (= triangle) in the source plane.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjabd7ecf6\" href=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf6_lr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=1gvrllJtU48Y6T%2B5%2Foh57eS2%2Fag%3D\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjabd7ecf6\" href=\"https://cfn-live-content-bucket-iop-org.s3.amazonaws.com/journals/0004-637X/911/2/99/1/apjabd7ecf6_hr.jpg?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAYDKQL6LTV7YY2HIK&amp;Expires=1636998456&amp;Signature=KKsWb9boTXwzsAUH5UNT0D%2BgQF4%3D\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>In the right panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjabd7ecf6\">6</a>, we present the source plane reconstruction of <em>z</em>6.3 (whole region), where the inset panel displays the source plane reconstruction of <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 (sub-region). To match the spatial resolution between HST and ALMA, we create a [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] map from the de-convolved [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] spatial distribution (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-1\">3.1</a>), smooth it with the point-spread function (PSF) of the HST F160W band, and use this PSF-matched map for the source plane reconstruction of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line. In the right panel, the white ellipses indicate the source plane reconstruction of the HST PSF, whose FWHM is decreased down to \u223c200 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 100 pc and \u223c300 <b>&#x00d7;</b> 60 pc around <em>z</em>6.3 and <em>z</em>6.1/6.2, respectively. The other colors and symbols follow the same assignment as the left panel, where we also apply the lens correction to the error bars. The error bar of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line peak position in <em>z</em>6.3 (red square) decreases to \u223c300 pc. These results indicate that we are able to map the ISM view down to the scale of a few hundred parsecs. Note that our independent mass models consistently suggest that the two-peak morphology of <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 in the image plane are a pair of multiple images (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-3\">3.3</a>), regardless of the presence or absence of a foreground object, and thereby correspond to one peak in the source plane. We confirm that the entire morphology in both whole and sub-regions of the galaxy, as well as the emission peak positions, do not change beyond the errors in the source plane whether or not we include the foreground galaxy overlapping <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 in the mass model as one of the member galaxies of RXCJ0600-2007.</p><p>Firstly, from the reconstruction of <em>z</em>6.3, we find that, on the galxy scale, the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line peak shows an offset of \u2243300 pc from the brightest rest-frame UV clump of a, but is consistent at the 1<em>\u03c3</em> error level. With an axis ratio of 0.49 (see Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjabd7ect4\">4</a>), nonparametric measurements directly on the surface brightness distributions in the source plane provide <em>r</em><sub>e</sub> = 1.1 kpc and 2.6 kpc for the rest-frame UV continuum and the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line emission, respectively, indicating a [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] gas structure spatially extended by a factor of \u223c2.4. These results are consistent with the recent ALMA results of Fujimoto et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib44\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib44\">2020b</a>) for 23 individual normal star-forming galaxies at <em>z</em> \u223c 4\u20136, whereby generally the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line is spatially more extended than the rest-frame UV continuum by a factor of \u223c2\u20133 without a spatial offset beyond \u2243a 1 kpc scale. The <em>r</em><sub>e</sub> value for the rest-frame UV continuum is also consistent with the S\u00e9rsic profile fitting results of 1.2 kpc in the source plane presented in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-5\">3.5</a>.</p><p>Secondly, from the reconstruction of <em>z</em>6.1/6.2, we find in the sub-region of the galaxy that the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line is again co-spatial with the rest-frame UV continuum, which is separated by \u223c1.6 kpc from the peak of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line and rest-frame UV continuum from the whole region of the galaxy. We mark the luminosity-weighted center of the sub-region with a black cross labeled <em>e</em>. Remarkably, we find, in the independent rest-frame UV continuum map reconstructed from <em>z</em>6.3, that the faint clump exists at exactly the position of <em>e</em>, whose peak flux density is also consistent. These agreements in the properties of clump <em>e</em> also support the robustness of our best-fit mass models. We also find that the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] and rest-frame FIR peaks observed in the image plane are reconstructed in the source plane with a \u22431 kpc offset from the luminosity-weighted center of <em>e</em>. This indicates that the faint diffuse emission or further faint clump near the caustic line is strongly lensed and more prominently visible in the image plane than clump <em>e</em>. Given that RXCJ0600-<em>z</em>6 is quantified by <em>r</em><sub>e</sub> = 1.2 kpc in the rest-frame UV continuum (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs3-5\">3.5</a>), these results indicate that we are witnessing very faint [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] and rest-frame FIR-emitting region(s) near the caustic line beyond the effective radius of the galaxy which is almost invisible in other multiple images. Because of the poor significance level of the rest-frame FIR continuum in <em>z</em>6.3, we cannot conclude whether the rest-frame FIR continuum detected in <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 corresponds to the outskirt emission of the whole galaxy or the localized emission at the sub region of the galaxy.</p><p>Interestingly, the brightest peaks of the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line and the rest-frame FIR continuum in <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 appear on opposite sides in the image plane (Left bottom panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjabd7ecf6\">6</a>). In <em>z</em>6.1/6.2, the magnification factor is generally the same on either side. The clear difference identified in the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line strength at high significance levels (8.2<em>\u03c3</em> and 5.4<em>\u03c3</em>) suggests the existence of a substructure of the mass distribution along the line-of-sight of <em>z</em>6.1/6.2, i.e., the so-called <em>flux-ratio anomaly</em> (e.g., Mao &amp; Schneider <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib83\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib83\">1998</a>). This is consistent with our interpretation that the central compact object in the optical\u2013NIR bands in <em>z</em>6.1/6.2 is the foreground object responsible for this <em>flux-ratio anomaly</em>. However, if the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] and rest-frame FIR-emitting regions are identical in the source plane, the flux ratio should be the same between the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] and rest-frame FIR emission in the image plane. Although the current error bars of the spatial positions are large, this independent observable of the flux ratio suggests that the faint [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] and rest-frame FIR-emitting regions are physically offset in the sub-region of RXCJ0600-<em>z</em>6. This potential separation, and the detailed ISM structure in RXCJ0600-<em>z</em>6 must be addressed in future deeper and higher-resolution observations.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjabd7ecs4-2\" name=\"apjabd7ecs4-2\">4.2.\u00a0Kinematics via [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>We also examine the kinematics of RXCJ0600-<em>z</em>6 via the bright [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line emission. Here we focus on the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] kinematics of <em>z</em>6.3 to characterize the gas kinematics of the whole galaxy. In the left panel of Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjabd7ecf7\">7</a>, we present velocity-integrated (top), velocity-weighted (middle), and velocity-dispersion (bottom) maps of <em>z</em>6.3 in the image plane. We evaluate the root-mean-square noise level from the data cube and create these maps with a three-dimensional (3D) mask of all signals above the the 2<em>\u03c3</em> level. We find that the [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] line has a velocity gradient from \u2212100 to +45 km s<sup>\u22121</sup> in east south to west north, with its intensity extended up to a radius of \u223c 1<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />4. Assuming the line width estimate of <em>z</em>6.3 (Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjabd7ect1\">1</a>), and a potential error of \u223c30 km s<sup>\u22121</sup> for the velocity gradient due to the spectral resolution of our ALMA data cube (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjabd7ecs2-1\">2.1</a>), we obtain \u0394<em>v</em><sub>obs</sub>/2<em>\u03c3</em><sub>tot</sub> = 0.94 \u00b1 0.26, where \u0394<em>v</em><sub>obs</sub> and <em>\u03c3</em><sub>tot</sub> are the full observed velocity gradient (uncorrected for inclination) and the spatially-integrated velocity dispersion, respectively. With an approximate diagnostic for the classification of rotation-dominated and dispersion-dominated systems, whereby \u0394<em>v</em><sub>obs</sub>/2<em>\u03c3</em><sub>tot</sub> = 0.4 (F\u00f6rster Schreiber et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib40\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib40\">2009</a>), we find that <em>z</em>6.3 is classified as a rotation-dominated system. Note that the beam smearing effect generally causes the velocity gradient [dispersion] to be underestimated [overestimated] in spatially low-resolution maps (see e.g., Figure 7 of Di Teodoro &amp; Fraternali <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjabd7ecbib32\" id=\"fnref-apjabd7ecbib32\">2015</a>).
